And concerning the types He loves, He said: <<إِنَّ الله يُحِبُّ التَّوَّابِينَ ويُحِبُّ الْمُتَطَهِّرِينَ>> (Indeed, Allah loves those who constantly repent and loves those who purify themselves), and He loves those who rely [on Him] (المُتَوَكِّلِينَ), and He loves the patient (الصَّابِرِينَ), and He loves the grateful (الشاكرين), and He loves those who give charity (المتصدقين), and He loves the doers of good (الْمُحْسِنِينَ), and He loves those who fight in His cause in [solid] ranks as if they were a structure joined firmly (بُنْيانٌ مَرْصُوصٌ). Just as He negated from Himself the love of a people due to attributes established in them that He does not love—the implication of the discourse is that He, the Glorified, loves their removal, and they are only removed by their opposite, necessarily—He said: <<إِنَّ الله لا يُحِبُّ الْمُفْسِدِينَ ولا يُحِبُّ الْفَسادَ>> (Indeed, Allah does not love the corrupters and does not love corruption). Its opposite is righteousness (الصلاح), so the very act of abandoning corruption is righteousness. And He said: <<إِنَّ الله لا يُحِبُّ الْفَرِحِينَ>> (Indeed, Allah does not love the exultant), and <<لا يُحِبُّ كُلَّ مُخْتالٍ فَخُورٍ>> (He does not love every self-deluded, boastful person), and <<لا يُحِبُّ الظَّالِمِينَ>> (He does not love the wrongdoers), and <<لا يُحِبُّ الْمُسْرِفِينَ>> (He does not love the extravagant), and <<لا يُحِبُّ الْكافِرِينَ>> (He does not love the disbelievers), and He does not love the public mention of evil speech (الْجَهْرَ بِالسُّوءِ من الْقَوْلِ), and <<لا يُحِبُّ الْمُعْتَدِينَ>> (He does not love the transgressors). Then, He, the Glorified, made things beloved to us, some through adornment and some absolutely. He said, conferring favor upon us: <<ولكِنَّ الله حَبَّبَ إِلَيْكُمُ الْإِيمانَ>> (But Allah has made faith beloved to you). And He said: <<زُيِّنَ لِلنَّاسِ حُبُّ الشَّهَواتِ>> (The love of desires has been adorned for mankind...) [the rest of the verse]. And concerning spouses, He said: <<وجَعَلَ بَيْنَكُمْ مَوَدَّةً ورَحْمَةً>> (And He placed between you affection [مودة] and mercy [رحمة]). And He forbade us from offering affection to the enemies of Allah, saying: <<لا تَتَّخِذُوا عَدُوِّي وعَدُوَّكُمْ أَوْلِياءَ تُلْقُونَ إِلَيْهِمْ بِالْمَوَدَّةِ>> (Do not take My enemy and your enemy as allies, extending to them affection [بِالْمَوَدَّةِ]). The mention of Love (المحبة) in the Quran is extensive. As for the Hadiths:

His saying (صَلَّى اللهُ عَليهِ وسَلَّم) reporting from Allah that He said: "I was a hidden treasure (كنزا لم أعرف) and I loved to be known (فأحببت أن أعرف), so I created the creation and introduced Myself to them, and they knew Me."

We were created only for Him, not for ourselves. Therefore, He linked recompense to deeds; thus, our deeds are for us, not for Him, and our worship is for Him, not for us. Worship is not the deed itself. The apparent deeds in creatures are His creation; He is the Doer. Their goodness is attributed to the creature out of courtesy (أدبا) toward Allah, despite the fact that all of it is from Allah, because He said: <<ونَفْسٍ وما سَوَّاها فَأَلْهَمَها فُجُورَها وتَقْواها>> (And [by] the soul and He who proportioned it and inspired it [with discernment of] its wickedness and its righteousness). And <<والله خَلَقَكُمْ وما تَعْمَلُونَ>> (And Allah created you and what you do). And Allah said: <<الله خالِقُ كُلِّ شَيْ‏ءٍ>> (Allah is the Creator of all things), and the deeds of the servants are included in that. And the Messenger of Allah (صَلَّى اللهُ عَليهِ وسَلَّم) said: "Indeed, Allah says: 'My servant does not draw near to Me with anything more beloved to Me than performing what I have obligated upon him. And My servant continues to draw near to Me through supererogatory deeds (النوافل) until I love him. When I love him, I am his hearing with which he hears, his sight with which he sees...'"

...[the rest of] the Hadith. It is from this Theophany (التجلي) that those who spoke of Unification (الاتحاد) derived their view, and from His saying: <<وما رَمَيْتَ إِذْ رَمَيْتَ ولكِنَّ الله رَمى‏>> (And you did not throw when you threw, but Allah threw), and from His saying: <<وما تَعْمَلُونَ>> (and what you do). And in the Hadith: "Indeed, Allah loves every afflicted, repentant one." And in the Hadith: "It is obligatory for those who love one another for My sake..." And in the Hadith: "Love Allah for the favors He has bestowed upon you." And in the Hadith: "Indeed, Allah is Beautiful and loves beauty," and "Indeed, Allah loves to be praised." And he (عليه السلام) said: "Three things from your world have been made beloved to me..." The Hadiths in this chapter are very numerous. Know that its station (مقامها) is noble, and it is the Origin of Existence (أصل الوجود).

From Love we originated,
And upon Love we were molded.

Therefore, we came to Him intentionally,
And for this, we were accepted.

This station has four titles:

### [The First Title] is Love (الحب)

This is its purity in the heart (القلب) and its clarity from the impurities of accidents (كدورات العوارض), so that the lover has no purpose or will alongside his Beloved.

(The Second Title) is Affection (الود)

This has a Divine Name, which is The Loving One (الودود). Affection (الود) is one of His descriptions, fixed in Him. By it, the stability (الثبوتة) in the earth is named *al-Wadud*.

(The Third Title) is Passionate Love (العشق)

This is the excess of Love (إفراط المحبة). It is alluded to in the Quran as intensity of love (شدة الحب) in His saying: <<والَّذِينَ آمَنُوا أَشَدُّ حُبًّا لِلَّهِ>> (But those who believe are stronger in love for Allah). And His saying: <<قَدْ شَغَفَها حُبًّا>> (Love has pierced her heart [شغفها]), meaning her love for Joseph became like the *shighaf* (الشغاف), which is the thin membrane that contains the heart, being a surrounding vessel for it. The Real described Himself in the Hadith with intense love, yet the name *‘ishq* (Passionate Love) and *‘ashiq* (Lover) are not applied to The Real. *‘Ishq* is the wrapping of love around the lover until it permeates all his parts and encompasses him completely, derived from the climbing plant (*al-‘ashqa*).

(The Fourth Title) is Inclination/Passion (الهوى)

This is the exhaustion of the will (استفراغ الإرادة) in the Beloved and the attachment to Him at the first moment it occurs in the heart. Allah does not have a Name derived from this. Its occurrence is caused by a glance, news, or beneficence, and its causes are numerous. Its meaning in the sound Divine Hadith is Allah's love for His servant when he increases supererogatory good deeds.

Likewise, following the Messenger in what he legislated. This is the rank in us named Passion (الهوى). Some have said concerning the love generated by news:

O people, my ear is passionately devoted to one of the tribe,
And the ear sometimes loves before the eye.

(And we have, concerning the love generated by sight and news, in the love poems [الغزليات]):

My love for others is dependent upon sight,
Except your Passion (هواك), for its foundation is upon news.

He knows that I have not known for her,
According to what was said to me, a sister among mankind.

So my goal in my seclusion is to attain her,
And that she may bestow upon my eye the favor of sight.

(And we also have concerning this meaning):

My Reality (حقيقتي) was passionately devoted to her,
But my sight did not see her.

Had it seen her, it would have become
A slain victim of that beauty.

So when I beheld her,
I became subject to the rule of sight.

I spent the night enchanted by her,
Wandering until dawn.

O my caution against my caution!
If only my caution would suffice me.

The Judgment (القضاء) and the Decree (القدر) ruled,
And it is only she who captivated me.

By Allah, I was not captivated
By the beauty of that shy one.

O her beauty, like a gazelle
Grazing in the place of wine (ذات الخمر).

When she glances or turns,
She captivates the minds of men.

She smiles, revealing teeth like hail, and
The fragrance of scattered clouds.

As if her breaths
Are the scents of fragrant musk.

As if she is the sun of the forenoon
In light, or like the moon.

If she unveils, the light of a bright morning
Brings her forth.

Or if she lets down her hair, the darkness
Of that hair conceals her.

O moon beneath the darkness,
Take my heart and leave

My eye, so that I may behold you,
Since my portion is sight.

For the foundation of my infatuation
With her love is from my news.

(And we also have concerning this meaning):

The ear is a lover and the eye is a lover,
How different is the love of the eye from the news!

The ear loves what my imagination pictures,
And the eye loves what is sensed in forms.

So the possessor of the eye, if the Beloved comes to him
One day for him to behold, he finds pleasure in the sight.

But the possessor of the ear, if the Beloved comes to him
In a sensible form, he does not cease to be in doubt.

Except the Passion (هوى) for Zaynab, for it is wondrous;
The portion of hearing and sight are equal in it.

The most subtle aspect of Love (الحب) that I have found is to experience excessive passion (*‘ishq*), inclination (*hawa*), disturbing longing (*shawq*), infatuation (*gharam*), emaciation, insomnia, and pleasure in food, yet not knowing for whom or by whom, and your Beloved is not specified. This is the subtlest taste (ذوق) I have found. Then, by agreement, either a Theophany (تجل) appears to you in an Unveiling (كشف), and that love attaches to it, or you see a person, and the ecstasy (وجد) you feel attaches to them upon seeing them, and you realize that was your Beloved, though you were unaware. Or a person is mentioned, and you find inclination toward them with that passion you possess, and you know that they are your companion. This is one of the most hidden subtleties of the soul's anticipation of things from behind the veil of the Unseen (حجاب الغيب). The soul is ignorant of its state and does not know by whom it is infatuated, nor in whom, nor what infatuated it. People find this in the contraction (*qabd*) and expansion (*bast*) for which no cause is known. Then, something that grieves him comes, and he knows that the contraction was for this matter, or something that delights him comes, and he knows that the expansion was for this matter. This is due to the soul's anticipation of matters before their formation in the attachment of the apparent senses, which are the preliminaries of formation. This resembles the taking of the Covenant (الميثاق) from the progeny that He is their Lord, which no one could deny thereafter. Thus, you find in the nature (فطرة) of every human a neediness for an Existent upon whom to rely, and that is Allah, though he is unaware of it. For this reason, He said: <<يا أَيُّهَا النَّاسُ أَنْتُمُ الْفُقَراءُ إِلَى الله>> (O mankind, you are the needy ones toward Allah). He tells them that the neediness you find in yourselves is attached to Allah and none other, but you do not know Him. The Real made Himself known to us through it. When we tasted this station, we said concerning it:

I was attached to the One I love for twenty years,
But I did not know whom I loved, nor did I know patience.

Nor did my eye ever look upon the beauty of her face,
Nor did my ears ever hear mention of her.

Until the lightning flashed from the side of the sanctuary (الحمى),
And it blessed me for a day and tormented me for an age.

And we also have concerning this meaning, based on taste (ذوقا), for we only express what we have tasted:

I was attached to the One I love from where I do not know,
And I do not know who is this one who said, "I do not know."

I have been perplexed in my state, and my thoughts have been perplexed,
And perplexities have been perplexed in me and in my affair.

While I was, after twenty years,
Interpreting a love that my secret (سرى) embraces,

I did not know whom I loved, nor did I know her name,
Nor did I know who this one was whom my breast contained.

Until her face appeared to me from her veil,
Like a night cloud revealing a full moon.

I asked them, "Who is this?" It was said, "This is
The daughter of the eye of the heart, the daughter of my brother, the sincere one (الصد)."

So I magnified her in reverence for her and for her origin,
For my night with her surpasses the Night of Decree (ليلة القدر).

And we have concerning this meaning, based on taste, when I first entered Damascus, I found an unknown inclination for a long period in a long Divine story imagined in a physical form. So we addressed her in that state and with its tongue:

I say, having with me the passion for you that I have,
The saying of one to whom the Beloved said, "Speak to me."

When I entered Damascus, my mind was confused,
I saw no lover before me like myself in Passion (الهوى).

I loved, but I did not know the one I loved,
Is my Beloved my Creator, or is He of my form?

Nor did my ears ever hear mention of Him,
Did any lover before us ever say this?

I traversed the lands of Allah, East and West,
Hoping to see a person who agrees with me in my state.

I saw none but a specific Beloved
Who naturally adheres to him, like the adherence of the shadow.

So I said, "O my God, my heart is infatuated,
And I did not know, so look upon my station and my humility."

Then the caller of Love (الحب) cried out from between my ribs,
"You have drowned, O wretched one, in the seas of ignorance!"

"Listen to my saying and take the secret of my wisdom,
For I am of the people of teachings and grace."

"By seven and ten, then fifty after them,
If you attain two upon my connection,"

"A wondrous square form will arise for you,
Perfectly upon the connection and the separation within it."

"Like the name Allah, a verified explanation,
So the name of my Beloved was upon the form of the Origin (الأصل)."

"That is the name of the one you love, if you are knowledgeable,
And this is from the knowledge added to stinginess."

"If you are a possessor of understanding, then seek nothing but
The triangle of the square, gathering the totality."

"Its triangle is a house, and a house is a scripture,
It has the beauty of coquetry that points to my guidance."

"A house for the eye of the essence, and then a house for the Glorious One,
They are the people of a house for generosity and giving."

"And its first is a pure, seven-fold letter,
From the six signs of the letters of separation."

### [The Station of the Love of Love (حب الحب), which is preoccupation with Love rather than its object]

This is the most subtle form of Love (المحبة), and beneath it is the love of Love (حب الحب), which is preoccupation with Love rather than its object. Layla came to Qays while he was crying out, "Layla! Layla!" and taking ice and placing it on his heart, which the heat of his heart melted. She greeted him while he was in that state and said to him, "I am your sought one, I am your desire, I am your Beloved, I am the coolness of your eye, I am Layla." He turned to her and said, "Go away from me, for your love has preoccupied me from you." This is the most subtle and delicate state in Love, but it is below what we mentioned in subtlety. Our Shaykh Abu al-Abbas al-’Uraybi, may Allah have mercy on him, used to ask Allah to grant him the desire for Love (شهوة الحب), not Love itself. People have differed in defining it, and I have not seen anyone define it by its essential definition (الحد الذاتي); indeed, that is inconceivable. Those who defined it only defined it by its results, effects, and necessary consequences, especially since the Glorious Presence, which is Allah, is described by it. The best I have heard concerning it is what was narrated to us by more than one person from Abu al-Abbas Ibn al-’Arif al-Sanhaji, who said they heard him say when asked about Love (المحبة): "Jealousy (الغيرة) is one of the attributes of Love, and jealousy refuses anything but concealment, so it cannot be defined."

### [That Known Matters are of Two Kinds: Those that are Defined and Those that are Not Defined]

Know that known matters (الأمور المعلومات) are of two kinds: those that are defined and those that are not defined. Love, according to the scholars who speak about it, is among the matters that are not defined. It is known by the one in whom it resides and the one whose attribute it is, but what it is is not known, nor is its existence denied.

### [The Love of a Thing Blinds and Deafens]

Know that every love that does not rule over its possessor such that it deafens him to every sound except what he hears from the speech of his Beloved, and blinds him to every sight except the face of his Beloved, and silences him from every speech except the mention of his Beloved and the mention of those who love his Beloved, and seals his heart so that nothing enters it except the love of his Beloved, and throws its lock upon the treasury of his Imagination (خيال) so that he imagines nothing but the form of his Beloved—either from a previous sight or from a description from which the Imagination creates a form—then it is as was said:

Your image is in my eye and your mention is on my mouth,
And your dwelling is in my heart, so where do you disappear?

Through Him he hears, and for Him he hears; through Him he sees, and for Him he sees; through Him he speaks, and for Him he speaks. The strength of my Imagination (الخيال) reached such a point that my love would embody my Beloved externally for my eye, just as Gabriel was embodied for the Messenger of Allah (صَلَّى اللهُ عَليهِ وسَلَّم). I could not look at Him, and He would address me, and I would listen to Him and understand from Him. He left me for days unable to swallow food. Whenever the table was presented to me, He would stand at its edge, look at me, and say to me in a tongue I heard with my ear, "You eat while you witness Me?" So I would abstain from food and find no hunger, yet I would be filled by Him until I grew fat and robust from looking at Him. He took the place of nourishment for me. My companions and family would wonder at my stoutness despite the lack of food, for I would remain many days without tasting anything, finding neither hunger nor thirst. But He never left my sight, whether I was standing, sitting, moving, or still.

### [Love Does Not Engross the Lover Completely Unless His Beloved is The Real, the Exalted]

Know that Love does not engross the lover completely unless his Beloved is The Real, the Exalted (الحق تعالى), or someone of his own species, such as a maidservant or a youth. As for anything other than those I have mentioned, his love for it does not engross him. We say this because the human is only met with his entire Essence (ذاته كلها) by one who is upon his Form (صورته) if he loves him. There is no part in him except that there is something corresponding to it in the Beloved, so no remainder is left in him by which he might become entirely sober. Thus, his exterior is infatuated with the Beloved's exterior, and his interior with the Beloved's interior. Do you not see that The Real named Himself The Manifest (الظاهر) and The Hidden (الباطن)? Thus, Love engrosses the human in The Real and in his likenesses. This is not the case with anything other than his species in the Cosmos (العالم). If he loves a form from the Cosmos, he only meets it with the appropriate part, and the remainder of his Essence stays sober in its occupation. As for the engrossment of his love when he loves Allah, it is because he is upon His Form, as mentioned in the Hadith. Thus, he meets the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) with his entire Essence. For this reason, all the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) appear in him, and he is characterized by them, whether he possesses the attribute of Love or not. This is why Love engrosses the human. If he is attached to Allah and Allah is his Beloved, he is annihilated (يفني) in His Love more intensely than his annihilation in the love of his likenesses. For in the love of his likenesses, he loses the manifest Beloved in his absence. But if The Real is the Beloved, He is perpetually witnessed (دائم المشاهدة). And the witnessing of the Beloved is like nourishment for the body; by it, it grows and increases. The more the witnessing increases, the more the love increases. For this reason, longing (الشوق) is calmed by meeting, yet yearning (الاشتياق) is aroused by meeting. This is what lovers find upon meeting the Beloved: they are never satisfied with witnessing Him, nor do they take their fill of Him, because every time they look at Him, their ecstasy (وجد) and longing increase, even while He is present with them, as was said:

And it is wondrous that I yearn for them,
And ask longingly about them, while they are with me.

And my eye weeps for them while they are in its blackness,
And my soul longs for them while they are between my ribs.

Any love in the lover that leaves a mind (عقل) by which he understands anything other than his Beloved, or a capacity for understanding, is not pure love; rather, it is a mere thought of the soul (حديث نفس). Some have said:

There is no good in a love that is managed by the mind.

The stories of lovers in this chapter are too numerous to count. And we have, concerning the increase of love with witnessing and longing:

I am absent, and longing annihilates my soul, so I meet,
But I am not satisfied, for longing is in absence and presence.

His meeting causes me what I did not expect,
Instead of healing, a new ailment of ecstasy (وجد).

Because I see a person whose beauty increases
When we meet, with pride and arrogance.

So there must be an ecstasy (وجد) that accompanies
The increase in the beauty of a well-ordered system.

I refer to His Theophany (تجلي) in different forms in the Hereafter to His servants, and in this world to the hearts of His servants, as mentioned in *Sahih Muslim* concerning His transformation into forms as befits His Essence (ذاته), without similitude or qualification (تكييف). By Allah, were it not for the Law (الشريعة) that brought the Divine news, no one would have known Allah. If we had remained with the rational proofs (الأدلة العقلية) that, in the claim of the rationalists, point to the knowledge of His Essence—that He is not such-and-such and not such-and-such—no creature would have loved Him. But when the Divine news came through the prophetic laws (الشرائع) that He, the Glorified, is such-and-such and such-and-such, matters whose apparent meanings contradict the rational proofs, we loved Him for these affirmative attributes. Then, after establishing the relationships and confirming the causes and relationships that necessitate Love, He said: <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him). Thus, the causes necessitating Love, which the intellect negated by its proof, were confirmed. This is the meaning of His saying:

"So I created the creation and introduced Myself to them, and they knew Me."

Allah is not known except by what He informed about Himself: His love for us, His mercy toward us, His compassion, His tenderness, His seeking to be loved, and His descent into limitation for the sake of His likeness, making Him the object of our sight in our hearts, in our direction of prayer (قبلتنا), and in our Imagination (خيالنا), until it is as if we see Him—no, rather, we see Him in us, because we knew Him by His definition, not by our own sight. And among us are those who see Him and are ignorant of Him. Just as He is not in need of others, so too, by Allah, He loves none other than Himself in existing things. He is the Manifest (الظاهر) in every beloved object for the eye of every lover. And there is no one in existence except a lover. The entire Cosmos (العالم) is a lover and a beloved, and all of that returns to Him, just as none but Him is worshipped. For whoever is worshipped is only worshipped through the imagination of Divinity (الألوهية) in him; were it not for that, he would not be worshipped. The Exalted says: <<وقَضى‏ رَبُّكَ أَلَّا تَعْبُدُوا إِلَّا إِيَّاهُ>> (And your Lord has decreed that you worship none but Him). Likewise, Love: no one loves anyone other than his Creator, but He is veiled from him by the love of Zaynab, Su’ad, Hind, Layla, the world, the dirham, and status. Every beloved object in the Cosmos—the poets exhausted their words on existing things while they were unaware. The Gnostics (العارفون) never heard poetry, riddles, praise, or love songs except about Him, from behind the veil of forms. The reason for this is the Divine Jealousy (الغيرة الإلهية) that anyone other than Him should be loved. For the cause of Love is Beauty (الجمال), and it belongs to Him, because Beauty is loved for its Essence (ذاته).

"Allah is Beautiful and loves beauty."

So He loves Himself. And the other cause is Beneficence (الإحسان), and there is no beneficence except from Allah, and no benefactor except Allah. If you love for beneficence, you have loved none but Allah, for He is the Benefactor. If you love for Beauty, you have loved none but Allah, the Exalted, for He is the Beautiful. In every aspect, the object of Love (المحبة) is none but Allah. When The Real knew Himself, He knew the Cosmos from Himself, so He brought forth the knowledge of His Form (صورته), and it became a mirror in which He sees His Form. Thus, He loved none but Himself. His saying <<يُحْبِبْكُمُ الله>> (Allah will love you) is, in reality, His love for Himself, since following is the cause of love, and following Him is His Form in the mirror of the Cosmos, which is the cause of love, because He sees none but Himself. And the cause of love is the supererogatory deeds (النوافل), which are additions. The form of the Cosmos is an addition to Existence (الوجود). So He loved the Cosmos as a supererogatory deed, and He became its hearing and sight, so that He loves none but Himself. What an obscure issue this is, and how quickly it escapes the imagination (الوهم)! For a strange thing has occurred in Existence: there are matters that the intellect (العقل) verifies and upon which it remains firm and unshaken, yet they escape the imagination, which cannot maintain control over them. Such is this issue: the intellect confirms it and cannot depart from it, yet it escapes the imagination, which cannot control it. And there are other matters that are the reverse: they escape the intellect but are confirmed in the imagination, which rules over them and is affected by them. For example, the intellect proves that one's provision (رزقه) must come to him, whether he strives for it or not. Yet this knowledge escapes the intellect, and the imagination rules over him with its authority, saying, "If you do not strive for it, you will die." So the imagination prevails over him, and he rises to work for its acquisition. His truth, from the perspective of his intellect, is gone, and his falsehood, from the perspective of his imagination, is fixed and unshaken. Likewise, one who sees a snake or a lion in a form that the intellect knows cannot harm him, yet he forgets that proof and imagines the harm, so he recoils from it, and his face and interior change by the rule and authority of the imagination. This exists. The imagination has authority in certain domains, and the intellect has authority in certain domains. We shall mention in this chapter, if Allah wills, some of the necessary consequences and stations of Love, as far as is facilitated.

### [That Love is a Specific Attachment of the Attachments of Will]

We say that Love (الحب) is a specific attachment of the attachments of the Will (الإرادة). Love only attaches to a non-existent thing (معدوم) at the time of attachment, desiring the existence of that Beloved or its occurrence. I said "or its occurrence" because it may attach to the non-existence of an existent thing, and the non-existence of an existent thing, while the existent thing is existent, is not occurring. When the existent thing to which Love attached ceases to exist, then it has occurred. It is not said that non-existence has been found, for that is ignorance on the part of the speaker. Our saying, "desiring the existence of that Beloved," and that the Beloved is, in reality, non-existent, is because what is beloved to the lover is a will that necessitated connection with this specific person, whoever he may be. If he is one who should be embraced, the lover loves his embrace; or one who should be married, he loves his marriage; or one who should be sat with, he loves sitting with him. His love only attached to something non-existent at that moment concerning this person. He imagines that his love is attached to the person, but it is not so. This is what excites him to meet and see him. If he loved his person or his existence in his essence, then he is in his personhood or in his existence, so there is no benefit in the attachment of love to him. If you say, "We used to love sitting with a person, or kissing him, or embracing him, or being intimate with him, or talking to him, and then we see that this is achieved, and the love does not cease with the existence of the embrace and union, so the object of love may not be non-existent," we say: You are mistaken. When you embrace the person to whose embrace, sitting, or intimacy the love attached, the object of your love at that moment is not the achieved thing, but rather the permanence and continuation of the achieved thing. And permanence and continuation are non-existent; they have not entered into Existence (الوجود), and their duration is endless. Therefore, Love only attaches, in the state of union (الوصلة), to a non-existent thing, which is its permanence. How excellent is what came in the Quran, His saying: <<يُحِبُّهُمْ ويُحِبُّونَهُ>> (He loves them and they love Him), using the pronoun of the absent and the future tense verb. He only attributed the object of love to an absent and non-existent thing, and every absent thing is relatively non-existent.

### [Among the Descriptions of Love is that the Lover Combines Two Opposites in His Love]

Among the descriptions of Love (المحبة) is that the lover combines two opposites in his love, so that his being upon the Form (الصورة) is correct, due to the choice (الاختيار) within it. This is the difference between Natural Love (الحب الطبيعي) and Spiritual Love (الروحاني). The human alone combines both, while animals love but do not combine two opposites, unlike the human. The human combines two opposites in his love because he is upon His Form, and He described Himself with two opposites in His saying: <<هُوَ الْأَوَّلُ والْآخِرُ والظَّاهِرُ والْباطِنُ>> (He is the First and the Last, the Manifest and the Hidden). The form of combining two opposites in love is that Love, by its necessary attributes, requires the love of connection with the Beloved. And by its necessary attributes, it requires the love of what the Beloved loves. If the Beloved loves separation (الهجر), and the lover loves separation, he has done what Love does not necessitate, for Love seeks connection. If he loves connection, he has done what Love does not necessitate, for the lover loves what his Beloved loves, and he did not do that. Thus, the lover is defeated in every case. The ultimate combination between the two is that he loves the Beloved's love for separation, not separation itself, and he loves connection. This issue does not extend beyond this, like the one who is content with the Divine Judgment (القضاء), for the name of contentment with the Judgment is correct for him, even though he is not content with the thing decreed (المقضي) if the decreed thing is disbelief, as the Law (الشرع) states. Similarly, in the matter of Love, the lover loves connection with the Beloved, and he loves the Beloved's love for separation, but he does not love separation itself, because separation is not the essence of the Beloved's love for separation, just as the Judgment is not the essence of the decreed thing. The Judgment is Allah's ruling with the decreed thing, not the essence of the decreed thing. Thus, he is content with Allah's ruling. The love of animals is not like this, because it is Natural Love (حب طبيعي), not Spiritual Love (روحاني). It seeks connection with the one it loves specifically, and it does not know that its Beloved has a love for such-and-such; it has no knowledge of that. For this reason, we divided the Love that is an attribute of the human into two types: Natural Love, by which he shares with beasts and animals, and Spiritual Love, by which he is separated and distinguished from the love of animals. If this is established, then we proceed.

### [Love is either Spiritual or Natural]

Know that Love is Divine (إلهي), Spiritual (روحاني), or Natural (طبيعي), and there is no love other than this. Divine Love (الحب الإلهي) is Allah's love for us, and our love for Allah may also be called Divine. Spiritual Love (الحب الروحاني) is that by which one strives for the pleasure of the Beloved, having no purpose or will alongside his Beloved; rather, he is subject only to what is willed for him. Natural Love (الحب الطبيعي) is that by which one seeks to attain all his own desires, whether that pleases the Beloved or not. Most people's love today is based on this. We shall first present the discourse on Divine Love in a section, followed by a section on Spiritual Love, and then a third section on Natural Love. <<والله يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the truth, and He guides to the way).

(The First Section) on Divine Love (الحب الإلهي)

This is that He loves us for us and for Himself. As for His love for us for Himself, it is His saying: "I loved to be known, so I created the creation and introduced Myself to them, and they knew Me."

We were created only for Himself, so that we might know Him. And His saying: <<وَ ما خَلَقْتُ الْجِنَّ والْإِنْسَ إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُونِ>> (And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me). He created us only for Himself. As for His love for us for our sake, it is due to the deeds by which we know Him, which lead us to our happiness and salvation from matters that do not agree with our purposes or suit our natures. He, the Glorified, created creation to glorify Him. Their utterance of glorification (التسبيح), praise, and prostration is for Him. Then He informed us of this, saying: <<وإِنْ من شَيْءٍ إِلَّا يُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِهِ>> (And there is not a thing except that it exalts [Him] by His praise), meaning by praising Him with what He is and what comes from Him. He also informed us, saying: <<أَ لَمْ تَرَ أَنَّ الله يُسَبِّحُ لَهُ من في السَّماواتِ والْأَرْضِ والطَّيْرُ صَافَّاتٍ كُلٌّ قَدْ عَلِمَ صَلاتَهُ وتَسْبِيحَهُ>> (Do you not see that to Allah glorifies whoever is in the heavens and on the earth, and the birds with wings spread? Each one has known its prayer and its glorification). So they adhered to that and persisted in it. He addressed His Prophet (صَلَّى اللهُ عَليهِ وسَلَّم), whom He made witness that and see it, with this verse, saying: <<أَ لَمْ تَرَ>> (Do you not see?), and did not say, "Do you not see (plural)?" For us, it is faith (إيمان), but for Muhammad (صَلَّى اللهُ عَليهِ وسَلَّم), it is direct vision (عيان). Likewise, He said to him when He made him witness the prostration of everything: <<أَ لَمْ تَرَ أَنَّ الله يَسْجُدُ لَهُ من في السَّماواتِ ومن في الْأَرْضِ والشَّمْسُ والْقَمَرُ والنُّجُومُ والْجِبالُ والشَّجَرُ والدَّوَابُّ وكَثِيرٌ من النَّاسِ>> (Do you not see that to Allah prostrates whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth, and the sun, the moon, the stars, the mountains, the trees, the moving creatures, and many of mankind?). He left no one out, for He mentioned whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth, mentioning the upper and lower Cosmos (العالم). He made him witness the prostration of everything. Everyone whom Allah makes witness that and see it falls under this address. This is an innate, essential glorification (تسبيح فطري ذاتي) resulting from a Theophany (تجل) that manifested to them, so they loved Him and were moved to praise Him without obligation, but by essential necessity. This is the essential worship (العبادة الذاتية) in which Allah established them by the rule of the entitlement that He deserves. Likewise, He said concerning the people of Unveiling (أهل الكشف), who are the generality of mankind and every rational being: <<أَ ولَمْ يَرَوْا إِلى‏ ما خَلَقَ الله من شَيْءٍ يَتَفَيَّؤُا ظِلالُهُ عَنِ الْيَمِينِ والشَّمائِلِ سُجَّداً لِلَّهِ وهُمْ داخِرُونَ>> (Do they not observe what Allah has created of things—their shadows incline to the right and to the left, prostrating to Allah, while they are humble?). This is the portion of visual bliss. Then He informed that this inclining right and left is prostration to Allah and submission and humility to His Majesty (جلاله), saying: <<سُجَّداً لِلَّهِ وهُمْ داخِرُونَ>> (prostrating to Allah, while they are humble). He described them by their own intellects, so they prostrated to Allah humbly. Then He informed, completing the matter: <<ولِلَّهِ يَسْجُدُ ما في السَّماواتِ وما في الْأَرْضِ من دابَّةٍ>> (And to Allah prostrates whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth of moving creature [دابَّة]), meaning those who move upon it, and <<وهُمْ>> (and they), meaning the inhabitants of the heavens, the angels, meaning those who are neither in heaven nor earth. Then He said: <<وهُمْ لا يَسْتَكْبِرُونَ>> (And they are not arrogant), meaning about the worship of their Lord. Then He described those among them who are commanded, that they do what they are commanded, and these are those concerning whom He said: <<لا يَعْصُونَ الله ما أَمَرَهُمْ ويَفْعَلُونَ ما يُؤْمَرُونَ>> (They do not disobey Allah in what He commands them but do what they are commanded). Then He said concerning those who are with their Lord: <<يُسَبِّحُونَ لَهُ بِاللَّيْلِ والنَّهارِ وهُمْ لا يَسْأَمُونَ>> (They glorify Him night and day, and they do not tire). All of this indicates that the entire Cosmos is in the station of Witnessing (الشهود) and worship, except every creature that has the power of reflection, which is only the rational human and jinn souls, specifically in terms of their essences (أعيان أنفسهم), not their structures, for their structures are like the rest of the Cosmos in glorifying and prostrating to Him. All the limbs of the body speak with His glorification. Do you not see them testifying against the souls that controlled them on the Day of Resurrection—the skins, hands, feet, tongues, hearing, sight, and all the faculties? <<فَالْحُكْمُ لِلَّهِ الْعَلِيِّ الْكَبِيرِ>> (So the judgment is for Allah, the Exalted, the Great). All of this is from the rule of His love for us for His own sake. Whoever fulfills his gratitude, He rewards him, and whoever does not fulfill it, He punishes him. So He loved His Essence (نفسه), and His magnification and praise are beloved. As for His love for us for our sake, He informed us of our interests in this world and the Hereafter, and established proofs for His Gnosis (معرفته) so that we might know Him and not be ignorant of Him. Then He provided for us and bestowed favors upon us despite our negligence, after our knowledge of Him and the establishment of the proof with us that every favor we enjoy is only from His creation and returns to Him, and that He only brought it into existence for our sake, so that we might enjoy it and subsist by it. He allowed us to lead and rule. Then, after this complete beneficence, we did not thank Him, although the intellect dictates gratitude to the Benefactor, and we knew that there is no benefactor but Allah. So, it is part of His beneficence that He sent to us a Messenger from Himself, a teacher and disciplinarian. He taught us what is for us in His Essence, legislated for us the path leading to our happiness, made it clear, and warned us against destructive matters and the avoidance of base and blameworthy morals. Then He established the proof of his truthfulness with us, bringing clear signs, casting the light of faith (الايمان) into our hearts, making it beloved to us, and adorning it in our hearts, and making disbelief, wickedness, and disobedience hateful to us. So we believed and affirmed. Then He favored us with success (التوفيق), employing us in what He loves and what pleases Him. Thus, we knew that were it not for His love for us, none of this would have occurred. Furthermore, His mercy preceded His wrath, and even if the wretched are wretched, they must eventually be encompassed by mercy, care, and the original Love (المحبة الأصلية) that affects the outcomes. Since Love preceded and the Word was confirmed and Mercy became universal, and since the lower world (الدار الدنيا) was a realm of mixing and veiling due to what the Almighty, the All-Knowing decreed, He created the Hereafter and transferred us to it. It is a realm that does not accept false claims. So everyone affirmed His Lordship there, just as they affirmed His Lordship in the grasp of the progeny (قبضة الذر) from the loins of Adam. Thus, we were in the lower world, a middle ground between two extremes: the extremes of Unification (توحيد) and affirmation. In the middle, polytheism (الشرك) occurred despite the confirmation of Existence (الوجود). The middle ground was weak, and that is why they said: <<ما نَعْبُدُهُمْ إِلَّا لِيُقَرِّبُونا إِلَى الله زُلْفى‏>> (We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah in position). They attributed greatness and majesty to Allah, the Exalted, even in their polytheism. Then the Exalted informed that He sealed the heart of everyone who appeared outwardly to his people with the attribute of arrogance and tyranny, and He did not place that in their hearts except by the seal of providence (طابع العناية). Thus, in their own souls, they are humble and submissive due to that seal. Arrogance never entered the heart of a creature concerning Allah originally, even if attributes of arrogance appeared from him; it is a manifest garment with no lining from him. All of this is from His mercy and His love for His creation, so that the outcome may be happiness. When the middle ground weakened and the two extremes strengthened, the matter prevailed in the end, and the House was filled. He placed bliss in each of the two Houses for its inhabitants, in which they will enjoy themselves after Allah has purified them by the torment they received, so that they may attain bliss in a state of purity. Do you not see how the one executed in retaliation is purified by that killing from the injustice of the murder he committed? The sword is an eraser. Likewise, the establishment of all legal punishments (الحدود) in this world is a purification for the believers, even the bite of a flea or the prick of a thorn. And there is another group upon whom the punishments of the Hereafter are established in the Fire, so that they may be purified, and then they are shown mercy in the Fire due to the preceding providence of Love (عناية المحبة). Even if they do not leave the Fire, Allah's love for His servants is not characterized by a beginning or an end (لا يتصف بالبدء ولا بالغاية), for He does not accept accidents or contingencies. Rather, the very Essence of His love for His servants is the very beginning of their being, the early ones and the later ones, to infinity. The relationship of Allah's love for them is the relationship of His Being (كينونته) with them wherever they were, in their state of non-existence (عدمهم) and in their state of existence. Just as He is with them in their state of existence, He is with them in their state of non-existence, because they are known to Him, witnessed by Him, and loved by Him. He has not ceased to be, nor will He cease to be. No ruling has become new upon Him that was not upon Him; rather, He has never ceased to love His creation, just as He has never ceased to know them.

His saying, "I loved to be known," is a definition for us of what the matter was in His Essence (نفسه). All of that is as befits His Majesty (جلاله). He is not conceived of, the Exalted, except as an Agent, a Creator. Every essence was non-existent in its own essence, known to Him, and its existence was beloved to Him. Then He brought existence into being for it—rather, He brought Existence into it—rather, He clothed it in the garment of Existence. So it was, then another, then another, in succession and continuity, from the first existent thing relying on the Primordiality (أولية) of The Real. There is no other existent thing, but a continuous Existence in individuals. The Last (الآخر) is in the genera and species, and individuals in creatures are only in a specific, finite type in the Hereafter, even if the world is finite. The universes (الأكوان) are new, and there is no end to their formation, because possibilities (الممكنات) are endless. So their eternity is perpetual, just as the Pre-eternity (الأزل) is fixed and necessary concerning The Real. There is no beginning to His Existence, so there is no beginning to His love for His servants. The mention of Love occurs with the Beloved upon the Divine definition, not Love itself. The Quran is the uncreated Speech of Allah, yet He said, defining what comes to them: <<ما يَأْتِيهِمْ من ذِكْرٍ من رَبِّهِمْ مُحْدَثٍ>> (No mention comes to them from their Lord that is newly revealed [مُحْدَثٍ]). So the mention is new *to us*, not in His Essence, from our Master, our Owner, our Reformer, and our Sustainer. And <<وما يَأْتِينا من ذِكْرٍ من الرَّحْمنِ مُحْدَثٍ>> (And no mention comes to us from the All-Merciful [الرَّحْمنِ] that is newly revealed). So the mention from the All-Merciful is new *to us*, not in His Essence. Mercy, favor, and beneficence are in the beginning, the consequence, and the outcome. No mention of the names of wretchedness occurred in the revelation; rather, it is Lord (رب) or All-Merciful (رحمن), to inform you of what is in His Essence for you.

(A Supplement on Divine Love)

This concerns our love for Allah, for Allah says: <<يُحِبُّهُمْ ويُحِبُّونَهُ>> (He loves them and they love Him). The attribution of Love to us is not the same as the attribution of Love to Him. The Love attributed to us, according to what our reality grants, is divided into two parts: one called Spiritual Love (حب روحاني) and the other Natural Love (حب طبيعي). We love Allah, the Exalted, with both loves together. This is an issue difficult to conceive, as not every soul is granted the knowledge of things as they are, nor are we granted faith in them in accordance with what came from Allah in His news about them. For this reason, Allah conferred favor upon His Prophet (صَلَّى اللهُ عَليهِ وسَلَّم) with such a matter, saying: <<وكَذلِكَ أَوْحَيْنا إِلَيْكَ رُوحاً من أَمْرِنا ما كُنْتَ تَدْرِي ما الْكِتابُ ولا الْإِيمانُ ولكِنْ جَعَلْناهُ نُوراً نَهْدِي به من نَشاءُ من عِبادِنا>> (And thus We have revealed to you an inspiration [روحاً] of Our command. You did not know what the Scripture was or [what] faith [was]. But We have made it a light by which We guide whom We will of Our servants). We, by the praise of Allah, are among those whom He willed of His servants. After the division of our love for Him, only four categories remain: either we love Him for Him, or we love Him for ourselves, or we love Him for the totality, or we love Him for none of the above mentioned. Here, another consideration arises: why do we love Him, since it is confirmed that we love Him, yet we do not love Him for Him, nor for ourselves, nor for the totality? What is this fourth matter? This is one section. And there is another division: if we love Him, do we love Him by ourselves, or do we love Him by Him, or do we love Him by the totality, or do we love Him by none of the above mentioned? All of this will be explained and discussed, if Allah wills. Likewise, in this supplement, we shall mention the beginning of our love for Him, and whether this love has an end in Him to which it terminates, or not. If it has an end, what is that end? This is an issue that no one has asked me about except a subtle woman from the people of this path. Then we shall also mention, if Allah wills, whether Love is a psychological attribute (صفة نفسية) in the lover, or an existential meaning (معنى وجودي) added to his essence, or whether it is a relationship (نسبة) between the lover and the Beloved that has no existence. All of this is required by this supplement.

### [That Love Does Not Accept Partnership]

Know that Love (الحب) does not accept partnership (الاشتراك). However, if the Essence (ذات المحب) of the lover is single and indivisible, then it does not accept partnership. If it is composite, it is permissible for its love to attach to different aspects, but for different reasons, even if the entity to which those different matters are attributed is one. Or, those matters may be in many individuals, so the love attaches to many, and the human loves many beloved ones. If it is correct for the lover to love more than one, it is permissible for him to love many, as the Commander of the Faithful said...

The three maidens took possession of my reins, / And settled in every place within my heart.

The secret lies in his use of "my reins" (عناني) in the singular. He did not give these beloveds different reins from himself. This indicates that although the lover is composite, he only loved one single meaning (معنى واحدا) that manifested for him in these three. That is, that meaning exists in the essence (عين) of each one of them. The proof of this is his statement in the rest of the verse: "And settled in every place within my heart." If he had loved a meaning in one that was not present in the other, the rein given to one would have been different from the rein given to the other, and the place occupied by one would have been different from the place occupied by the other. This is one who loved one, and that beloved One exists in many; thus, he loved the many for the sake of that One.

This is like our love for Allah (الحق). Some of us love Him for His own sake, and some of us love Him for the totality (للمجموع). The latter is more complete in love because it is more complete in gnosis (المعرفة) of Allah and Witnessing (الشهود). Some of us know Him through Witnessing and thus love Him for the totality. Some of us know Him not through Witnessing but through report (الخبر) and love Him for that. Some of us know Him through blessings and love Him for our own sake. Some of us love Him for the totality. This is because Witnessing only occurs in a form (صورة), and the form is composite, and the lover possesses a composite form. Thus, he hears from one aspect and loves Him based on the report, such as His saying, through the tongue of His Prophet: "Have you befriended a friend for My sake, or opposed an enemy for My sake?"

If you love things for His sake and oppose things for His sake, this is the meaning of our love for Him, nothing else. So we fulfill all that He loves us to fulfill willingly (عن طيب نفس). And he who does not witness Him in my form is in the position of a subordinate (في حكم التبع), just as our limbs and our animality are subordinate to the rational soul (النفس الناطقة). They cannot disobey it because they are like tools (كالآلات) for it, which it directs as it wishes, whether in the pleasure of Allah or outside of His pleasure. Every part of the human limbs, if left to its own consideration, cannot act except in what pleases Allah, for it belongs to Him. All things in Existence (الوجود) are of this nature, except the two weighty ones (الثقلان). This is His saying: <<وَإِنْ مِنْ شَيْءٍ إِلَّا يُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِهِ>> (And there is not a thing except that it glorifies Him with praise). By this glorification (التسبيح), He means praise (الثناء) of Allah, not for recompense (الجزاء), because it is an essential worship (عبادة ذاتية) with which the seeking of reward is inconceivable. This stems from its love for Him, the Exalted, except for some rational souls. Because the reflective faculty (القوة المفكرة) was placed in them regarding the gnosis of Allah, they were not created upon the innate knowledge of Allah.

For this reason, He seized them in the grasp of the progeny (قبض الذرية) from their loins and <<وَأَشْهَدَهُمْ عَلَى أَنْفُسِهِمْ>> (made them testify concerning themselves) by a testimony of compulsion (شهادة قهر). So they prostrated to Allah reluctantly, not willingly, due to the seizure upon them. Then He released them, freed from that specific grasp, yet they remain seized without realizing it. They imagined they were free. When the soul found itself governing this dark structure (الهيكل المظلم), it proceeded in matters according to what its own purpose dictated. It loves nothing except what suits its nature (طبعها) and became heedless of the station of acknowledging Lordship (الربوبية) to its Originator (موجدها).

While it was thus, the reflective faculty said to it: "I have used all the faculties, but you have neglected me and abandoned me, though I am one of your tools. You have no concern for me. Use me!" The soul replied: "Yes, do not blame me, for I was ignorant of your rank. I permit you to act according to what your reality dictates until I realize what you are, so that I may direct you and utilize you." The faculty said, "I hear and obey." Then the reflective faculty turned its face back to the soul, like a teacher, and said: "You have been heedless of your Essence (ذاتك) and your Existence. Have you always existed thus, by your own Essence, or were you not, and then you came to be?" The soul said, "I was not, and then I came to be." The thought faculty said: "Is this one who brought you into being (كونك) your own essence (عينك) or other than you? Reflect, verify, and use me, for this is my function."

So the soul reflected and knew, by what the evidence granted it, that it did not originate itself and that it exists for the sake of another. Thus, the indigence (الفقر) toward its Originator is essential (ذاتي), due to what it finds within itself of natural pains (الآلام الطبيعية). It becomes dependent on customary means (الأسباب المعتادة) to remove those pains. Through this dependence, it knew that it is poor (فقيرة) in the existence of its own essence, needing the originating cause (السبب الموجد لها). When its contingency (حدوثها) was established, and it was established that it has a cause that brought it into existence, it reflected further and knew that this cause should not resemble it by being poor like it. And that this cause is not comparable to the means that remove its pains, because it witnesses the contingency of these means after they were not, and their susceptibility to transformation and corruption. Thus, it was established for the soul that it has an Originator who brought it into existence and brought into existence all contingent things (الحوادث) that resemble it, and the means that remove its pains.

It became aware that there was a matter (أمرا ما) without which it would have remained sick and ailing. Out of His mercy for it, He brought into existence these means that remove its pains. The soul had loved these means and naturally gravitated toward them. Then the attachment of that love shifted to the Cause that originated those means. It said: "He is more worthy of my love, but I do not know what pleases Him so that I may deal with Him accordingly." Thus, love for Him was established within it. It loved Him for the blessing of its own existence and the existence of what suits it. Here it paused, yet throughout all this, it was heedless and forgetful of its acknowledgment of the Lordship of its Originator during the grasp of the seed.

While it was thus, a caller (داعي) came to it from outside, of its own kind, claiming to be a Messenger from this One who brought it into existence. The soul said to him: "You are like me, and I fear you may not be truthful. Do you have anyone who confirms you? For I have a reflective faculty by which I reached the gnosis of my Originator." He presented evidence that confirmed his claim. The soul reflected upon it until his truthfulness was established for it, and it believed in him. He informed it that the Originator who brought it into existence had seized it and made it testify concerning His Lordship, and that it had testified to Him concerning that. The soul said: "I have no knowledge of that, but from now on, I will fulfill the obligation of that acknowledgment, for you are truthful in your report. But I do not know what pleases Him in my actions. If you would define boundaries (حدودا) and prescribe rituals (مراسم) for me to adhere to, so that you may know that I am among those who fulfill their gratitude for what He has bestowed upon me."

So he prescribed for it what was legislated (شرع). It fulfilled this out of gratitude (شكرا), even if it contradicted its own purpose (غرضها). It did not do this out of fear or desire (خوفا ولا طمعا). This is because when He initially prescribed what He prescribed, He informed it that its adherence to those rituals pleased Him, but He did not mention what reward it would receive, nor what punishment it would incur if it disobeyed. This pure soul (النفس الزكية) hastened to His pleasure in that, saying, "There is no god but Allah," as it was told.

Only after that did He inform it of the great reward (الثواب الجزيل) and complete bounty (الإنعام التام) it would receive, and the punishment for those who violate His law. Thus, another form of worship was added to its worship out of pure love and contentment—a worship sought out of desire for reward (رغبة في الثواب) and fear of punishment (رهبة من العقاب). So, in its worship, it combined two things: worship for His sake and worship out of desire and fear. It loved Him for His sake and for its own sake, insofar as it is multiple (كثيرة) by its nature and spirituality. Desire and fear became attached through its nature (طبيعتها), and its worship of Him became attached through love (محبة له) from its spirituality (روحانيتها). If it loves anything else in existence, it loves it through its spirituality for His sake, and through its nature for the attainment of its own purpose.

When the Real (الحق) saw it thus, and knew that division (الانقسام) is inherent in its reality, and yet it had combined the two loves, and He had described Himself with jealousy (الغيرة), He did not desire partnership. He wished to purify the soul for Himself so that it would love none other than Him. So He disclosed Himself (تجلى لها) to it in a natural form (صورة طبيعية) and gave it a sign (علامة) that it could not deny within itself—this is what is expressed as necessary knowledge (العلم الضروري). It knew that He was this form. It inclined toward Him spiritually and naturally. When He possessed it and knew that the means (الأسباب) must affect it due to its nature, He gave it a sign by which it would recognize Him. Then He disclosed Himself to it through that sign in all the means. So the soul recognized Him and loved the means for His sake, not for their own sake. Thus, it became entirely His, not for its nature nor for any other cause. It saw Him in everything, and it rejoiced and was delighted, seeing that it had been favored over other souls by this Reality (الحقيقة).

Then He disclosed Himself to it in the very essence of its natural and spiritual self (عين ذاتها الطبيعية والروحانية) with that sign. It saw that it only saw Him *by* Him, not by itself, and only loved Him *by* Him, not by itself. He is the one who loved Himself; the soul did not love Him. It looked upon Him in every existent thing with that eye—its own eye—and knew that none other than Him loved Him. He is the Lover (المحب) and the Beloved (المحبوب), the Seeker (الطالب) and the Sought (المطلوب). It became clear to it through all this that its love for Him was for His sake and for its own sake. What it witnessed in this other level (المرتبة الأخرى) of its love for Him was only *by* Him, not *by* itself, nor by the totality. There is no added factor except non-existence (العدم). It desired to know the measure and limit of that love, so it paused at His saying:

"I was a Hidden Treasure (كنزا لم أعرف) and I loved to be known (فأحببت أن أعرف)."

It had known Him when He disclosed Himself to it in a natural form, and it knew that He deserved the name the Manifest (الظاهر) and the Hidden (الباطن) from that form in which He appeared. It knew that the love by which He loved to be known is only in the Hidden attributed to Him. It knew that the lover, when standing in the form, must breathe (يتنفس) due to the pleasure of the Sought (المطلوب) in that breathing. That breath (النفس) emerged from the origin of love in the creation (الخلق) whom He wished to be known by, so that they might know Him.

This was the Cloud (العماء), named the Real by which creation occurred (الحق المخلوق به). That Cloud became the substance (جوهر) of the world (العالم). It accepted all the forms, spirits, and natures of the world, and it is receptive to what is infinite. This is the beginning of His love for us. As for our love for Him, its beginning is hearing, not sight. This is His saying to us, while we were established in the substance of the Cloud: "Be!" (كن). The Cloud is from His breath (تنفسه), and the forms, expressed as the World, are from the word "Be!" (كلمة كن). We are His inexhaustible words. Allah the Exalted said: <<وَكَلِمَتُهُ أَلْقَاهَا إِلَى مَرْيَمَ>> (And His Word which He cast unto Maryam)—which is Jesus—<<وَرُوحٌ مِنْهُ>> (and a Spirit from Him)—which is the breath. That Reality flows through the animal kingdom. If Allah wills its trust (أمانته), He removes the breath from it. By the breath was its life. (The forms of formations in the world resulting from the breath will come in the chapter on the Soul.)

When we heard His speech while we were established in the substance of the Cloud, we could not stop ourselves from existing. So we became forms in the substance of the Cloud. By our manifestation in the Cloud, we gave existence to the Cloud; after its existence was merely intelligible (معقولي الوجود), it attained concrete existence (الوجود العيني). This was the cause of the beginning of our love for Him. For this reason, we move and feel delight upon hearing melodies, due to the word "Be!" emanating from the Divine Form, both hidden and witnessed. The witnessed form of the word "Be!" consists of two letters: *Kaf* (ك) and *Nun* (ن). Similarly, the world of witnessing (عالم الشهادة) has two faces: outer and inner. Its outer is the *Nun*, and its inner is the *Kaf*. For this reason, the articulation point of the *Kaf* in man is deeper, belonging to the world of the Unseen (عالم الغيب), as it is one of the last throat letters, between the throat and the tongue. The *Nun* is a tongue letter. The hidden aspect of this word is the *Waw* (و) between the *Kaf* and the *Nun*, which is a lip letter. It has manifestation, but it is a weak letter (حرف علة), not a strong letter (حرف صحيح). For this reason, formation (التكوين) resulted from it, because it is a weak letter. Since it is a lip letter, with the extension of the breath from outside the lips to the manifest cosmos, this is why the ruling (الحكم) in the body appears for the spirit. Acts and movements appear from the body because of its spirit, and its spirit is hidden, because the *Waw* has no existence in the witnessed world (الشهادة) since it is elided due to its quiescence and the quiescence of the *Nun*. Thus, it acts from behind the veil. It is absent in essence but manifest in its ruling.

The limit of our love for Him is that we know the reality of what love is: Is it a psychological quality (صفة نفسية) of the lover, or an inherent meaning (معنوية) in him, or a relationship (نسبة) between the lover and the beloved—the connection (العلاقة) that draws the lover to seek union (الوصلة) with the beloved?

We say it is a psychological quality of the lover. If it is said, "We see it disappear," we reply: "Its disappearance is impossible except with the disappearance of the lover from Existence, and the lover does not disappear from Existence. Therefore, love does not disappear." What is conceived as disappearing is only its attachment to a specific beloved (محبوب خاص). That specific attachment and relationship to that particular beloved can disappear, and it can become attached to another beloved. Since it is attached to many beloveds, the relationship between the lover and a specific beloved may be severed, yet love itself remains existing within the lover, for it is the very essence (عين) of the lover. Its disappearance is impossible.

Love is the very soul and essence of the lover, not an inherent quality (صفة معنى) that can be removed, thereby removing its effect. The relationship is the proportion (النسبة) between the lover and the beloved, and love is the essence of the lover, nothing else. Attribute love to whomever you wish, contingent or otherwise, for love is nothing other than the essence of the lover. There is nothing in Existence except a lover and a beloved. But the nature of the beloved is that it must be non-existent (معدوما) and must be brought into existence, or it must occur (وقوعه) in an existent thing (موجود), not in a non-existent thing. This is a verified, necessary matter. The relationship that is in the lover is only in that existent thing which accepts the existence of that beloved, or its occurrence, not its existence, if the beloved cannot be described by existence but only by occurrence. An example of this is when a person loves the non-existence (إعدام) of an existing thing because of the harm its existence causes him, such as pain (الألم). Pain is an existent thing in the sufferer, so he loves its non-existence. His beloved is non-existence, which is not occurring. If the pain ceases, its removal is its non-existence after its existence, by its transition to non-existence. For this reason, in such a case, we speak of occurrence (الوقوع) not existence. The beloved is always non-existent. Love for an existent thing is not valid entirely, except in terms of the relationship, since the relationship only attaches to an existent thing in which the existence of that non-existent beloved appears. We have explained this before in this chapter. Thus, the nature (ماهية) of love, its beginning, and its limit have become clear to you in this completion, as well as by what the lover loves, and whether his love is for his beloved or for himself. All this has been clarified. We shall now turn to the discussion of the Second Connection, if Allah wills. What has been achieved regarding Divine Love (الحب الإلهي) is sufficient for the present time. *End of the 112th Part.*

(In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful)

**The Second Connection: On Spiritual Love (الحب الروحاني)**

This is the comprehensive love (الحب الجامع) in which the lover loves his beloved for the sake of the beloved and for his own sake, since Natural Love (الحب الطبيعي) only loves the beloved for the sake of the lover himself.

### [What is Love, the Meaning of the Lover, the Reality of the Beloved, and What is Desired from the Beloved?]

Know that if the lover in Spiritual Love is described by intellect (العقل) and knowledge (العلم), he is wise by his intellect and knowing by his wisdom. He arranges matters according to the order of wisdom and does not transgress their stations. Thus, he knows, when he loves, what love is, what the meaning of the lover is, what the reality of the beloved is, and what he desires from the beloved. Does his beloved have will and choice, so that the lover loves what the beloved loves, or does the beloved have no will, so the lover only loves for his own sake? Or is the existent thing (الموجود) that does not will the existence of its beloved except within the essence of that existent thing? To this extent, we say that the existent thing is beloved, even if the beloved is only *in* it, not *itself*. If that existent thing is one that is described by will (الإرادة), then it is possible for the lover to love it for its sake, not for his own sake. If it is not described by will, then the lover only loves his beloved for his own sake—meaning, for the sake of the lover, not for the sake of the beloved. For the beloved is not described as having love for anything or a purpose. However, the existent thing in which this beloved is found may possess will. In this case, it becomes incumbent upon the lover to love what that existent thing loves, and thus he loves it for its sake, but subordinately (بحكم التبع). This is what love grants, for the lover seeks union (الوصلة) essentially (بذاته) after seeking the existence of his beloved. For the very existence of his beloved is the very essence of his union; this is necessary. This is our saying:

The time of Existence is the time of Union, / The time of Affection (الوداد): eat and drink!

This verse is from a poem of ours concerning the manifestation of a reality (حقيقة) that disclosed itself to us in a station of witnessing (حضرة شهودية):

I was astonished by Zaynab in passion (al-hawa), / And we have no doctrine other than her.
When a light disclosed itself to us, / It illuminated the heart, and the darkness vanished.
She sacrificed her soul for her, out of jealousy / For her, though passion is ever exhausting.
There was no interval of time / Between the attainment of passion and the achievement of desire.

Because when passion is attained, breathing (التنفس) and sighing occur, and the breath emerges in the form of the beloved's image (صورة المحبوب) conceived in the lover's soul. It manifests it as an external form that he witnesses, and thus he achieves his goal and bliss through it without time, as mentioned previously regarding the existence of the Cloud (العماء). We completed the poem by saying after this:

I was astonished by Allah's mercy upon me, / And at such a thing, one ought to be astonished.
The time of Affection is the time of Existence, / The time of Union: eat and drink!
Where is the ardent love (al-gharam), where is the sickness, / And where is the intense passion (al-hiyam)? Be astonished!
Pure of garment, veiled, / She is not attributed to anyone.

For the beloved, as we said, must be non-existent (معدوما). In its state of non-existence, it is "pure of garment" (طاهر الثوب) when it first comes into existence, because it has not acquired anything that blemishes or defiles it in its first appearance and existence. The origin is purity. This is His saying: "Every newborn is born upon the primordial nature (الفطرة)," which is purity. And our saying "veiled" (محجوبة) is its non-existence, which we mentioned, from the witnessing of Existence. And our saying "She is not attributed to anyone" is because the non-existent is not attributed, but the lover seeks it for himself. Then we completed it, and this is the end of the poem:

Gratitude is due to Allah, for / She is the virgin (al-bikr) for me, and I am the non-virgin (al-thayyib).

Because the beloved came into existence from non-existence, it is a virgin, and I had loved before that, so I am a non-virgin. If the beloved, which is the non-existent, when it comes into existence, does not exist in an existent thing described by will, then this lover is not described as willing it for the beloved's sake, but loves it for his own sake by necessity, like Natural Love. If the beloved only exists in an existent thing described by will, such as the Real the Exalted, or a maiden, or a youth, and there is nothing else to which the lover's love attaches except those we mentioned, then it is valid for him to love what this existent thing loves, in which his beloved only exists. If it happens that this existent thing does not will what this lover loves, the lover remains upon his original principle in loving his beloved, because his beloved has no will, as we said. Thus, it is not necessary for him to love what this existent thing loves, which does not love what this lover loves, since that existent thing is not the essence of the beloved, but only the locus (محل) for the existence of that beloved. It is not within the power of the lover to bring that beloved into existence in this existent thing, unless he is enabled by the Real. However, if the beloved is one whose existence is not in an existent thing, the lover cannot bring the beloved into existence at all, unless a special providence (عناية) from the Real supports him and grants him formation (التكوين), like Jesus (peace be upon him) and whomever Allah wills among His servants. If this is granted, love necessarily compels him to bring his beloved into existence. This is an issue you will not find verified as we have mentioned it in any book other than this, for I have not seen anyone verify what we have mentioned concerning it, even though lovers are many—indeed, everyone in Existence is a lover—but they do not know the object of their love. They are veiled by the existent thing in which their beloved is found, so they imagine that existent thing is their beloved, but this is not the case. Know the measure of what I have informed you of. The truth is that no one loves a beloved for the sake of the beloved itself; rather, he loves it for his own sake. This is the verification. For the non-existent is not described by will, so that the lover might love it for its sake and abandon his own will for the will of his beloved. Since the matter is not essentially thus, it remains only that he loves it for his own sake. Understand this. This is Spiritual Love (الحب الروحاني) stripped of the natural form. If it clothes itself in it and appears in it, as we said in Divine Love, it is closer in proportion to Spiritual Love, because in any case, it is a form among the forms of the world, even if it is above nature.

### [When the Spirit Accepts the Natural Form]

Know that when the spirit (الروح) accepts the natural form in the imaginative bodies (الأجساد المتخيلة), not in the sensible bodies (الأجسام المحسوسة) that are customarily perceived. Imaginative bodies are also customarily perceived, but not everyone who witnesses them distinguishes between them and what they consider real bodies. For this reason, the Companions did not recognize Gabriel when he descended in the form of a Bedouin, and they did not know that it was an imaginative body until the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) informed them, saying, "This is Gabriel." No doubt arose in their minds that he was an Arab. Similarly, Mary when the Angel appeared to her as <<بَشَراً سَوِيًّا>> (a man perfectly formed), because she had no sign regarding spirits when they materialize. Similarly, the Real (الحق) will appear to His servants on the Day of Resurrection, and they will seek refuge from Him due to their lack of recognition. Thus, the ruling concerning the Divine Presence (الجناب الإلهي) and the Spiritual Presence (الروحاني) in forms is the same regarding the ignorance of the one to whom the disclosure occurs. Therefore, for the one whom Allah cares for, there must be a sign by which he recognizes the disclosure (تجلي) of the Real from the disclosure of the Angel, from the disclosure of the Jinn, from the disclosure of humans, when they are given the power to appear in forms, like a swaying branch (قضيب البان) and its likes. If a human, with this elemental, earthly constitution, has the power to transform into forms in the eye of the beholder while remaining in his own form, then this transformation is even more likely for spirits. Know whom you see, and by what you see, and what the matter truly is. We have explained this in the chapter on Gnosis in the science of Imagination (علم الخيال); look for it there.

If the spirit discloses itself in a natural form, the ruling applies to it exactly as we mentioned in Divine Love, in terms of that form's acceptance of the Manifest (الظاهر) and the Hidden (الباطن). It does not deviate from that course. Know this. Thus, the spiritual lover combines Natural Love and Spiritual Love, and combines loving for his own sake and for his beloved's sake, if his beloved, as we said, possesses will. It becomes clear to you, based on what we have established, that people do not know what they love, and that their beloved is subsumed within an existent thing, so they imagine that existent thing is their beloved, but this is not the case. Know the measure of what I have informed you of, and thank Allah for having delivered you from ignorance concerning me. This much is sufficient for the intended purpose, for it contains many ramifications, and our purpose in this book is to establish the fundamental principles (الأصول). Praise be to Allah.

**The Third Connection: On Natural Love (الحب الطبيعي)**

It is of two types: natural and elemental (عنصري). We forgot to mention the limit of Spiritual Love, so let us mention it in the context of Natural Love.

Since Spiritual Love relates to the natural form (الصورة الطبيعية), its limit is union (الاتحاد). This is that the essence of the beloved becomes the very essence of the lover, and the essence of the lover becomes the very essence of the beloved. This is what the doctrine of Incarnation (الحلولية) refers to, though they have no knowledge of the true nature of the matter. Know that the natural form, in whatever state it appears—whether as a body (جسم) or a structure (جسد), in whatever proportion—the beloved, which is the non-existent, even though non-existent, is represented in the Imagination (الخيال). Thus, it has a type of existence perceived by the imaginative sight (البصر الخيالي) in the Imaginative Presence (الحضرة الخيالية) with the eye appropriate for it.

When the two lovers embrace, and each one sucks the saliva (ريق) of the other, and that saliva dissolves into the essence of each lover, and each of the two forms breathes during kissing and embracing, so that the breath (نفس) of one enters the interior of the other, and the breath of the other enters the interior of the first—the animal spirit (الروح الحيواني) in natural forms is nothing but that breath. Every breath is the spirit of each of the two breathers, and the one who received it has been brought to life by it during the act of breathing and kissing. Thus, what was the spirit of Zayd becomes precisely the spirit of Amr. That breath had emerged from a lover and taken the form of love, accompanied by the pleasure of love. When it became a spirit in the one to whom it transferred, and the breath of the other became a spirit in the latter, this was expressed as union (الاتحاد) concerning each of the two persons. It is valid for him to say:

I am the one I love, and the one I love is me.

This is the limit of Spiritual Love in natural forms. This is what is meant by his saying in the poem at the beginning of this chapter: "Spirit with spirit, and body with body."

Then we return to Natural Love and say that Natural Love is the general type, for all the preceding types of love in those described by them accepted natural forms according to what their realities dictated. Thus, in their love, they were characterized by what natural forms are characterized by: ecstasy (الوجد), longing (الشوق), yearning (الاشتياق), loving the meeting with the beloved, seeing him, and connecting with him. Many sound reports (أخبار كثيرة صحاح) have been transmitted concerning this, which must be believed, such as His saying: "Whoever loves the meeting with Allah, Allah loves the meeting with him." This is despite the fact that He has never ceased to be present to him (من عينه), and it is not possible for Him to cease to be present to him, for He is <<عَلَى كُلِّ شَيْءٍ شَهِيدٌ>> (Witness over everything) and an Observer. Yet, He mentioned the meeting (اللقاء) concerning Himself and His servant.
