He also described Himself as yearning (الشوق) for His servants, and that He rejoices more intensely and loves the repentance of His servant more than the one whose riding camel, carrying his food and drink, is lost in a desolate land, and then he finds it after despairing of life and being certain of death.

How great is His joy in finding it! Allah rejoices more intensely at the repentance of His servant than that person rejoices at his riding camel, despite His self-sufficiency, power, and the execution of His will upon His servants. But look into the secret of His saying: <<أَعْطَى كُلَّ شَيْءٍ خَلْقَهُ>> (He gave everything its creation/nature), and you will know that He did not transgress the deservedness of matters, and that the level of Knowledge (العلم) is above all other levels. He said: <<مَا يُبَدَّلُ الْقَوْلُ لَدَيَّ>> (The word is not changed with Me), because it contradicts the Known (المعلوم), so its occurrence is impossible. Although the matter is possible (ممكن) when viewed in itself, it is not possible when viewed in relation to Allah's Knowledge concerning the occurrence of one of the two possibilities, and the oneness of the Will (المشيئة) concerning it. What the Divine Will has attached to must come into being. What must occur cannot be described as possible (الإمكان) when viewed in relation to this reality. For this reason, some observers in this field have refrained from applying the name "possible" to it, preferring the name "Necessary Existence by Another" (واجب الوجود بالغير). This is more appropriate in verification, due to the oneness of the Will. For this reason, He said, "If He willed," where He did not say "If" as a particle of impossibility for impossibility. The Will has preceded as it preceded, as He said: <<وَلَقَدْ سَبَقَتْ كَلِمَتُنَا لِعِبَادِنَا الْمُرْسَلِينَ>> (And Our Word has already preceded for Our servants, the Messengers). Thus, the name "Necessary Existence by Another" is more complete in attributing the matter than the name "possible," since there is only one matter, <<كَلَمْحٍ بِالْبَصَرِ>> (like the twinkling of an eye). Thus, the possibility vanished, and the contingency vanished. There is only absolute necessity or restricted necessity. Then we return and say:

### [That Natural Love, by its Essence, when it resides in the lover, only loves the beloved for the bliss derived from it]

Know that Natural Love, by its essence, when it resides in the lover, only loves the beloved for the bliss (النعيم) and pleasure (اللذة) derived from it. Thus, it loves it for its own sake, not for the essence of the beloved. It has become clear to you in the preceding discussion that this reality flows through Divine Love and Spiritual Love. The beginning of Natural Love is not due to bounty or beneficence, for nature (الطبع) does not recognize that entirely. Rather, it loves things purely for its own sake. It desires connection (الاتصال) and closeness to them. This is prevalent in every animal, and in man insofar as he is an animal. The animal loves it essentially (في نفس الأمر) for the sustenance of its existence (لقوام وجوده), not for any other reason. But the animal does not know the meaning of the sustenance of its existence. It only finds an inner impulse (داعية) to connect with a specific existent thing. That connection is its beloved essentially (بالأصالة). This only occurs in a specific existent thing, so it loves that existence subordinately (بحكم التبعية), not essentially. Its connection is a sensible connection and a sensible closeness. This is our saying: "And body with body." This is the limit of Natural Love. If it is marriage (نكاحا), its beloved essence is found in a specific existent thing, and its limit is the attainment of that beloved in existence. It seeks and yearns for the locus (المحل) in which the essence of its beloved appears, and it only appears between the two of them, not in one of them, because it is a relationship between two. The same applies whether it is embracing, kissing, companionship, or whatever it may be. There is no difference between saying the nature of a thing or its reality; all are permissible expressions for it.

It is more complete in man than in others because he combines the realities of the world and the Divine Form. He has a relationship to the Most Holy Presence (الجناب الأقدس), for he appeared from Him and came into being from His word "Be!" He has a relationship to the spirits through his spirit, and to the world of nature and elements through his body, based on his constitution. He loves everything that the elements and nature seek essentially. There is nothing but the world of bodies, structures, and spirits. Among them are elemental bodies, and every elemental body is natural. Among them are natural bodies that are not elemental. Not every natural body is elemental. The elements are among the natural bodies, but they are not called elemental. Likewise, the celestial spheres and the angels. For this reason, we know that the Highest Assembly (الملأ الأعلى) dispute, and thus they fall under His saying: <<وَلَا يَزَالُونَ مُخْتَلِفِينَ إِلَّا مَنْ رَحِمَ رَبُّكَ>> (And they will not cease to differ, except those upon whom your Lord has mercy). They oppose those upon whom mercy is shown, and <<وَلِذَلِكَ خَلَقَهُمْ>> (And for that He created them)—meaning, He created them for the sake of difference. This is because the Divine Names are differentiated (متفاضلة). From there, opposition (الخلاف) arose. Where is the Harmful (الضار) compared to the Beneficial (النافع)? The Exalter (المعز) compared to the Abaser (المذل)? The Withholder (القابض) compared to the Extender (الباسط)? Where is heat compared to cold, wetness to dryness, light to darkness, non-existence to existence, fire to water, yellow bile to phlegm, movement to stillness, servitude to Lordship? Are these not opposites? <<وَلَا يَزَالُونَ مُخْتَلِفِينَ>> (And they will not cease to differ). Where is the lawful compared to the forbidden concerning the same essence for two persons? What is forbidden to one is lawful to the other, so two different rulings apply to a single essence. Look at the ruling of opposing nature (الطبيعة المتضادة): from where did it originate, and what was the cause of its existence as opposites, stemming from Divine Knowledge? This is so you may know that none of the created beings other than Allah possesses any authority (الأمر), neither in this world nor in the Hereafter, even though the Hereafter has two abodes: vision and veil. Praise be to Allah who clarified matters for us, their sources and their destinations, and made us among those who know them. May Allah make us among those whom He has blessed with His knowledge.

It has become clear to you that the beloved is the connection (الاتصال) with a specific existent thing, whether many or few, and whether it is companionship, sitting together, kissing, embracing, or anything else, according to what the reality of the existent thing in which the beloved essence resides dictates, and according to the reality of the lover. The beloved is one essence but varied: it is the love of connection specifically, whether through conversation, hugging, or kissing. This is its variation in one or many. It is not valid for the lover to love two beloveds essentially, because the heart cannot contain them. If you say, "This may be true for the love of creation, but not for the love of the Creator, for He said, <<يُحِبُّهُمْ>> (He loves them), so He loved many," we reply: Love is an intelligible meaning. Even if it cannot be defined, it is perceived by taste (الذوق) and is not unknown, but it is difficult to conceive. Its relationship to Allah the Exalted is unknown, for <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him). Your statement, "But not for the love of the Real," is an arbitrary judgment from you, for only one who knows the Essence of the Real would say this, and the Essence is not known. Thus, the relationship is not known. But love is known, for He only addressed His servants in their own language and with what they know in their idiom concerning everything He attributes to Himself and describes Himself with, but the modality of that is unknown.

(Connection) As for the second division, which is Elemental Love (الحب العنصري):

Although Elemental Love is natural, there is a difference between the two types. Natural Love is not restricted to one natural form over another; it is with every form just as it is with the next in love, like amber with what attaches to it, holding it by its property. Elemental Love is restricted to a single natural form, such as Qays for Layla, Qays for Lubna, Kathir for Azza, and Jamil for Buthayna. This only occurs due to a general suitability (عموم المناسبة) between them, like a magnet for iron. It resembles the station of Spiritual Love: <<وَمَا مِنَّا إِلَّا لَهُ مَقَامٌ مَعْلُومٌ>> (And there is none of us but has a known station). It resembles Divine Love in being restricted to a single creed (عقيدة واحدة) over others, just as Spiritual Love resembles Natural Love in purity, and Divine Love resembles Natural Love in seeing one essence in all creeds.

### (Connection) [Love has Four Titles]

Know that love, as we have said, has four titles (ألقاب). For each title, there is a state within it that is the very essence of the other. Let us clarify all of this.

**1. Al-Hawa (Inclination/Passion):** This is said in two ways, both being the same type of love: its falling into the heart (سقوطه في القلب), which is its appearance from the Unseen (الغيب) into the witnessed world (الشهادة) in the heart. It is said, "The star inclined (هوى النجم)" when it fell. Allah the Exalted says: <<وَالنَّجْمِ إِذَا هَوَى>> (By the star when it inclines/falls). So it is one of the names of love in that state. The verb is *hawa yahwi* (with *kasra* on the middle letter in the past and *fatha* in the future), and the noun is *hawa* (Inclination).

The meaning of *al-hawa* arises in the heart from one of three things, or some of them, or all of them: sight (نظرة), hearing (سماع), or beneficence (إحسان). The greatest of these is sight, and it is the most stable, for it does not change upon meeting. Hearing is not like that, for it changes upon meeting, as it is unlikely that the image formed by imagination through hearing will match the form of the person mentioned. As for the love of beneficence, it is conditional (معلول) and is removed by heedlessness, even with the continuation of beneficence, because the essence of the benefactor is not witnessed.

The second type of *Hawa* only occurs in the context of the ruling of the Law (الشريعة). This is His saying to David: <<فَاحْكُمْ بَيْنَ النَّاسِ بِالْحَقِّ وَلَا تَتَّبِعِ الْهَوَى>> (So judge between the people with truth, and do not follow inclination/passion). Meaning: Do not follow your loves (محابك), but follow My loves, which is judging according to what I have prescribed for you. Then He said: <<فَيُضِلَّكَ عَنْ سَبِيلِ اللَّهِ>> (Lest it lead you astray from the path of Allah)—meaning, it will confuse you, destroy you, and blind you to the path I have legislated for you and asked you to follow, which is judging by it. Here, *al-hawa* refers to human loves. The Real commanded him to abandon his loves if they contradicted the prescribed path.

If you say, "He forbade him from something that cannot be stopped, for the authority of love (*al-hawa*) is strong, and the essence of the intellect has no existence alongside it," we reply: He did not burden him with removing *al-hawa*, for it does not disappear. However, as we said, *al-hawa* differs in its object of attachment and can exist in many existent things. We have explained that the reality of *al-hawa* (which is love) is the love of connection in a specific existent thing or many. So, Allah asked him to attach it to the Real that He legislated for him, which is the path of Allah (سبيل الله), just as he attaches it to many paths that are not the path of Allah. This is the meaning of <<وَلَا تَتَّبِعِ الْهَوَى>>. He did not burden him with what he cannot bear, for burdening with the impossible (تكليف ما لا يطاق) is impossible for the Wise Knower to legislate.

If you argue with the burden of faith (تكليف الايمان) upon those whom Allah knew beforehand would not believe, like Abu Jahl and his likes, we reply in two ways. The first answer is that I only mean by burdening with the impossible that which is customarily impossible for the burdened person to bear, such as telling him to ascend to the sky without means, or to combine two opposites, or to stand at a time when standing is impossible. Rather, He burdened him with what is customarily possible for him to bear, which is believing or uttering the faith, both of which every person finds the ability to do, whether by acquisition or creation, however you wish to say it. For this reason, the conclusive argument (الحجة) is established by Allah against the servant on the Day of Resurrection. He said: <<قُلْ فَلِلَّهِ الْحُجَّةُ الْبَالِغَةُ>> (Say: To Allah belongs the conclusive argument). If He had burdened him with what was not customarily within his capacity, His saying <<فَلِلَّهِ الْحُجَّةُ الْبَالِغَةُ>> would not be valid. Rather, He would say, "And Allah does what He wills," as He said: <<لَا يُسْأَلُ عَمَّا يَفْعَلُ>> (He is not questioned concerning what He does). The meaning of this is that the Real is not asked, "Why did You burden us, forbid us, and command us, despite Your knowledge of what You decreed upon us of disobeying You?" This is the context of <<لَا يُسْأَلُ عَمَّا يَفْعَلُ>>. For He will say to them, "Did I command you with what you are able to bear, or what you are not able to bear, in your view?" They must say, "With what we are customarily able to bear." Thus, it is established that <<لِلَّهِ الْحُجَّةُ الْبَالِغَةُ>>, for they are ignorant of Allah's knowledge concerning them during the time of the burden. The second answer has already been established: that faith is necessary, and it occurred in Allah's grasp of the seed. Its ruling will appear in the Hereafter, and only a believer will remain. In this worldly abode, he acknowledges His existence, and even if he associates partners, he only associates partners with an existent thing. For this reason, He only asked him for the unification of the command (توحيد الأمر) specifically for Him. This is the beloved of the Real, and it is non-existent in them. He loves for His unification to appear in these existent beings. Thus, if one is characterized by it, Allah loves him because His beloved, which is unification (التوحيد), appeared in him. And if one is hated, it is because His beloved did not appear in him, which is unification. All incline toward faith, and we have established this in the precedence of Mercy over Allah's Wrath. Thus, the meaning of *al-hawa* has become clear to you.

**2. Al-Hubb (Love/Purity):** Love is when this inclination (*Al-Hawa*) is purified in its attachment to the path of Allah, excluding all other paths. When it is purified and clear of the turbidities of the partners (الشركاء) from the paths—those whom the polytheists made partners with Allah in divinity—it is called *Hubb* (Love) due to its clarity and purity. From this, the water jar (الحب) is named *Hubb*, because water clarifies and settles in it, and its sediment descends to the bottom. Similarly, love in creatures, when it attaches to the Divine Presence (جناب الحق) and is purified for Him from its relationship with the rivals (الأنداد) whom the polytheists made partners with Allah in divinity, is called *Hubb*. Indeed, Allah the Exalted said concerning it: <<وَالَّذِينَ آمَنُوا أَشَدُّ حُبًّا لِلَّهِ>> (And those who believe are stronger in love for Allah). The reason for this is that when the veil is lifted, <<وَتَبَرَّأَ الَّذِينَ اتُّبِعُوا مِنَ الَّذِينَ اتَّبَعُوا... وَقَالَ الَّذِينَ اتَّبَعُوا لَوْ أَنَّ لَنَا كَرَّةً فَنَتَبَرَّأَ مِنْهُمْ كَمَا تَبَرَّءُوا مِنَّا>> (those who were followed will disown those who followed... and those who followed will say, 'If only we had a return, we would disown them as they disowned us'). Their love for them vanishes in that station, and the believers remain steadfast in their love for Allah. Thus, they are stronger in love for Allah because they surpassed the others at the time when the others turned away from loving their deities when they availed them nothing against Allah. Only their love for Allah specifically remains with the polytheists on the Day of Resurrection, for in this world they loved Him and loved their partners on the basis that they were deities. Were it not for that delusion and error, they would not have loved them. Thus, their beloved was divinity (الألوهة), and they imagined it in many, so they loved Him and loved the partners. When the Resurrection occurs as we mentioned, nothing remains with them except their love for Allah the Exalted. Thus, in the Hereafter, they are stronger in love for Allah than they were in this world, because their love was divided, but it gathered upon Him in the Hereafter when they witnessed their beloved, which is divinity, only in Him specifically. For this reason, Mercy preceded, and the strength of the two extremes and the weakness of the middle ground due to the partnership within it. We have explained all of this previously. This is the difference between *Hubb* and *Hawa*.

**3. Al-'Ishq (Ardent Passion):** *Al-'Ishq* is the excess of love (إفراط المحبة) or excessive love. This is His saying concerning the believers: <<أَشَدُّ حُبًّا لِلَّهِ>> (stronger in love for Allah). It is when the quality named *Hubb* takes hold and manifests in the kernel of the heart (حبة القلب)—which is also why it is named *Hubb*—and then encompasses the entire person, blinding him to everything other than his beloved. That reality flows through all parts of his body and his faculties and his spirit, running through him like blood in his veins and flesh, overwhelming all his joints, connecting with his existence, and embracing all his parts, body and spirit. No space remains for anything else. His speech becomes by Him, his hearing from Him, and his sight in everything is toward Him. He sees Him in every form and says, "It is this," whenever he sees anything. At that point, that love is called *Ishq*. This is like what was narrated about Zulaikha, that when she was bled, the blood fell to the ground, and "Yusuf, Yusuf" was written in many places where the blood fell, because the mention of his name ran like blood in all her veins. Similarly, it was narrated about Al-Hallaj, when his limbs were cut off, "Allah, Allah" was written in his blood on the ground wherever it fell. For this reason, he said (may Allah have mercy on him):

No limb or joint of mine remains / Except that in it is a remembrance of You.

This belongs to this category. These are the ardent lovers (العشاق) who were consumed by love in this manner. This is what is called *al-gharam* (ardent love), and its description will come in the description of the lovers, if Allah wills.

**4. Al-Wudd (Steadfast Affection):** *Al-Wudd* is the permanence (ثبات) of love, or *Ishq*, or *Hawa*—whatever state this quality may be in. When the person described by it remains steadfast upon it, and nothing changes him from it or removes him from its ruling, and its authority remains firm in ease and hardship, in what is bad and what is pleasing, in the state of abandonment and expulsion from the existent thing in which he loves his beloved to appear, and he does not depart from under its authority because it is the manifestation of his beloved—it is called *Wudd*. This is His saying: <<سَيَجْعَلُ لَهُمُ الرَّحْمَنُ وُدًّا>> (The Most Compassionate will grant them affection/steadfast love)—meaning, permanence in love with Allah and in the hearts of His servants. This is the meaning of *al-wudd*.

Love has many states in the lovers, which I shall mention, if Allah wills, such as longing (الشوق), ardent love (الغرام), intense passion (الهيام), infatuation (الكلف), weeping, sadness, anguish (الكبد), emaciation (الذبول), brokenness (الانكسار), and similar states with which lovers are described and which they mention in detail in their poems, if Allah wills.

Many errors occur in love. The first is what we mentioned: that they imagine the beloved is an existent thing, whereas it is a non-existent thing (أمر عدمي) to which love attaches, desiring to see it existing in an existent essence. When he sees it, his love shifts to the permanence of that state whose existence he loved in that existent essence. Thus, the beloved remains non-existent, and most lovers are unaware of this, unless they are Gnostics (عارفين) concerning the realities and their attachments. Most of our discussion in this chapter concerns excessive love (المحبة المفرطة), for it removes the intellects or causes emaciation, perpetual thought, constant anxiety, restlessness, insomnia, longing, yearning, change of state, dullness of mind, distraction (الوله), foolishness (البله), and suspicion toward the beloved—meaning the existent thing in which you love the appearance of your beloved, which the common people claim is the beloved for them.

We are of two types concerning this: one group of us looked at the image (المثال) in their imagination (خيالها) of that existent thing in which their beloved appears, and they witness the existence of their beloved—which is connection (الاتصال) with it—in their imagination. They witness it connected to them with a subtlety (لطف) greater than its subtlety in its external existence. This is the one who was distracted by Qays the Madman from Layla when she came to him externally, and he said to her, "Go away from me, lest the density of the sensible (كثافة المحسوس) veil me from the subtlety of this imaginative witnessing (المشاهدة الخيالية)." For in his imagination, she is subtler and more beautiful than in her external essence. This is the subtlest form of love, and the possessor of this quality is perpetually in bliss and does not complain of separation. We have the upper hand in this quality among lovers, for such a state is rare among lovers due to the dominance of density over them. The reason for this, in our view, is that whoever is consumed in the love of meanings abstracted from matter, his limit, if he densifies them, is to bring them down to the Imagination (الخيال), and he does not bring them down further. So, if the Imagination is the clearest state for him, what do you think of his subtlety in meanings? This person, whose state is this, is the one who can love Allah, for his limit in loving Him, if he does not strip Him of anthropomorphism (التشبيه), is to bring Him down to the Imagination. This is His saying (peace be upon him): "Worship Allah as if you see Him."

When we, being of this quality, love an existent thing—a sensible thing from the world of densities—in which we love the appearance of our beloved, we subtle-ize it by raising it to the Imagination so that we may clothe it with beauty beyond its beauty and place it in a Presence (حضرة) where separation and departure are impossible. Thus, he remains in perpetual connection. Concerning this, we say:

The Madman of Banu Amir has nothing from his passion / Except the complaint of distance and alienation.
But I am his opposite, for my beloved / Is in my imagination, so I am never far.
My beloved is from me, within me, and with me, / So why should I say, "What ails me, what ails me?"

As for our saying that love removes the intellects, they said: "There is no good in a love that is managed by the intellect." And Abu al-Abbas al-Maqrani said: "Love is more possessive of souls than intellects." They said this because the intellect restricts its possessor, while confusion (الحيرة) and straying (الضلال) are among the descriptions of love. Confusion contradicts the intellect, for the intellect gathers you, while confusion disperses you. Joseph's brothers said to Jacob: <<إِنَّكَ لَفِي ضَلَالِكَ الْقَدِيمِ>> (Indeed, you are in your ancient straying), meaning his confusion in the love of Joseph. Confusion disperses and does not gather. For this reason, love is described by *al-bathth* (dispersion/scattering), which is the scattering of the lover's concerns in many directions. Allah the Exalted said: <<وَبَثَّ مِنْهُمَا رِجَالًا كَثِيرًا وَنِسَاءً>> (And dispersed from both of them many men and women). Likewise, His saying: <<هَبَاءً مُنْبَثًّا>> (scattered dust). The lover is under the ruling of his beloved, so he has no self-management. Rather, he is governed by what the authority of love, which dominates his heart, grants and commands him.

Among his straying in his love is that he imagines that his beloved is beautiful in the eyes of every person, and that everyone sees in him what this lover sees. This is from confusion. On this runs the proverb: "Beautiful in every eye is the one you love"—meaning, in your view, O lover, you imagine that everyone who sees your beloved finds him beautiful, just as you do. Among the straying of the lover is that he becomes confused about the ways (الوجوه) through which he sees that he attains his beloved. He says, "Shall I do this to reach my beloved through this action, or that?" He remains confused about which way to proceed, because he imagines that the existence of pleasure with his beloved in the senses is greater than in the imagination. This is due to the dominance of density (الكثافة) over this lover. He is heedless of the pleasure of imagination during sleep, for it is a stronger connection than his pleasure through the waking imagination, and connection through the imagination is stronger than connection through the external (sensible) world. Thus, the lover is confused about achieving the ways by which he reaches external connection, and he asks about this from one who he knows has knowledge of this matter, hoping to find a stratagem (حيلة) with him, especially since he has heard the saying of the poet:

If your passion (al-hawa) were true, you would be guided to stratagems.

Meaning, in what you should do to connect with the beloved.

The first of the attributes of the Lovers (المحبين) that I shall mention is what Yunus ibn Yahya ibn Abi al-Hasan al-Hashimi al-Qassar related to us in Mecca, facing the Yemeni Corner of the Venerable Kaaba, in the year 599 AH. He said: Ibn Abd al-Baqi informed us; Ahmad ibn Ahmad informed us; Ahmad ibn Abdullah informed us; Abdullah ibn Muhammad ibn Ja'far related to us; Abu Bakr al-Dinawari the Exegete related to us in the year 288 AH; Muhammad ibn Ahmad al-Shamshati related to us. He said: I heard Dhu al-Nun say:

Indeed, Allah has servants whose hearts He has filled with the pure clarity of His Love, and whose spirits He has expanded with longing (الشوق) for His Vision. Glory be to Him Who made their souls long for Him, brought their understanding close to Him, and purified their breasts for Him. Glory be to Him Who grants them success, Who comforts their loneliness, and Who is the physician of their ailments. My God, their bodies have humbled themselves before You, and their hands have stretched out toward the increase that comes from You. You have made them taste of the sweetness of understanding You, by which You have made their lives pleasant and perpetuated their bliss. You have opened the gates of Your heavens for them and permitted their hearts to roam in Your Kingdom (ملكوتك). Nay, You have not forgotten the love of the Lovers, and upon You rests the reliance of the longing ones (المشتاقين). To You the hearts of the Gnostics (العارفين) yearn, and by You the hearts of the truthful ones (الصادقين) are comforted. Upon You the fear of the fearful ones (الخائفين) is focused, and in You the hearts of the deficient ones (المقصرين) seek refuge. Rest has despaired of their lassitude, and the greed of heedlessness has diminished in them. They do not settle into the conversation of thought concerning what does not concern them, nor do they tire of effort and wakefulness. They secretly converse with Him with their tongues and supplicate Him with their humility, asking Him for pardon for their slips and forgiveness for the errors that occurred in their deeds. They are those whose hearts have melted with the contemplation of sorrows, and who served Him with the service of the righteous (الأبرار).

Among their attributes, may Allah be pleased with them, is Emaciation (النحول). This is an attribute related both to their dense aspects (كنائفهم) and their subtle aspects (لطائفهم).

As for its relation to their subtle aspects, although the spirits of the Lovers are too subtle for the perception of the senses and too subtle for the depiction of the Imagination (الخيال), Love makes them subtle with the subtlety of a mirage (السراب), for a reason I shall mention. That is because the thirsty one <<thinks it is water>> (يَحْسَبُهُ الظَّمْآنُ ماءً), and this is due to his thirst; otherwise, he would not think it water, because water is the object of his need, so he resorts to it because it is his desired object and beloved, due to the secret of life it contains. Then, <<when he comes to it, he finds nothing>> (إِذا جاءَهُ لَمْ يَجِدْهُ شَيْئاً). And when he finds nothing, <<he finds Allah with him>> (وَجَدَ الله عِنْدَهُ) as a substitute for the water. His intention was sensory water, but Allah is intended through it, without him realizing it. Just as He, the Exalted, plots against the servant without the servant realizing it, so too does He care for the servant in his seeking refuge in Him, returning to Him, and relying upon Him, by cutting off the means (الأسباب) from him when He displays them to him, without the servant realizing it. Thus, the finding of Allah with him upon the loss of the water imagined in the mirage is his return to Allah when the means have been cut off and the doors to his desired object have been closed. He returns to the One <<in Whose Hand is the dominion of all things>> (بِيَدِهِ مَلَكُوتُ كُلِّ شَيْ‏ءٍ), and He was the object sought through Allah. This is His action with His beloved ones: He returns them to Himself, whether by necessity or by choice.

Similarly, their spirits imagine themselves to be fulfilling the rights of Allah that He has obligated upon them, and that they are acting by the command of Allah, out of love for Allah and longing for His pleasure, so that He may see them where He commanded them. But when the veil (الغطاء) is lifted for them and their sight sharpens, they find themselves like the mirage in the form of water. They see no one fulfilling the rights of Allah except the Creator of Acts, Who is Allah the Exalted. Thus, they find Allah to be the very essence (عين) they imagined to be their own essence. Their essence vanishes from Him, and the witnessed Reality (المشهود الحق) remains by the Eye of the Real (بعين الحق), just as the water of the mirage vanished from the mirage. The mirage itself is existent in itself, but it is not the doer (فاعل). It is known then that the Lover is the very Essence of the Beloved (عين المحبوب), and that he has loved none other than Him. It cannot be otherwise. This subtlety of Emaciation (النحول) in the spirits is the most subtle, and it does not occur otherwise.

As for the type of Emaciation related to their dense aspects (كثائفهم), it is what the senses perceive: the change in their colors and the wasting away of the flesh of their bodies, due to the dominance of their thoughts roaming in the fulfillment of what the Beloved has charged them to fulfill of His obligations. They exert their utmost effort to be characterized by the fulfillment of covenants, since they had covenanted with Allah and contracted upon it in their faith in Him and His Messenger. They heard Him commanding: <<O you who have believed, fulfill the contracts>> (يا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا أَوْفُوا بِالْعُقُودِ). And He said: <<Fulfill My covenant>> (أَوْفُوا بِعَهْدِي) and <<Do not break the covenant, and you have made Allah a guarantor over you>> (وَلا تَنْقُضُوا الْمِيثاقَ وَقَدْ جَعَلْتُمُ الله عَلَيْكُمْ كَفِيلًا). This is the cause of the emaciation of their bodies.

Among the attributes of the Lovers is Wasting (الذبول). This is a true attribute in their spirits and their bodies. As for their bodies, its cause is the abandonment of delicious foods that contain fat and moisture, which are pleasurable to the souls and impart the freshness of bliss to the bodies. When they realized, may Allah be pleased with them, that the Beloved charged them to stand before Him and converse with Him at night during His Theophany (تجلي) while the sleepers slept, and they saw that the moisture generated in their bodies sends vapors up to the brain that dull the senses and overwhelm them, causing sleep to overcome them, preventing them from standing before their Beloved for conversation in their solitude while others sleep—and furthermore, those vapors generate strength in their bodies that leads the limbs to engage in excesses (الفضول) which their Beloved has forbidden them from engaging in—they abandoned food and drink except for what is absolutely necessary. Thus, the moisture in their bodies decreased, the freshness of bliss departed from them, their lips withered, their bodies relaxed, their sleep vanished, and their wakefulness strengthened. They thus attained their goal of standing before Him and found assistance in this through what they abandoned. That is the wasting of the bodies.

As for the wasting of their spirits, they possess bliss through Gnosis (المعارف) and sciences (العلوم), because they have a connection to the spirits of the High Assembly (الملإ الأعلى) so that they may find comfort in their own kind, desiring mutual assistance, having heard Allah the Exalted say: <<And cooperate in righteousness and piety>> (وتَعاوَنُوا عَلَى الْبِرِّ والتَّقْوى). They imagined that they were the ones addressed by this, but the matter is not so. For those addressed by this are those who are prone to cooperating in sin and aggression. That is why He followed it with a prohibition, saying: <<And do not cooperate in sin and aggression, and fear Allah>> (وَلا تَعاوَنُوا عَلَى الْإِثْمِ والْعُدْوانِ واتَّقُوا الله). This is not among the characteristics of the High Assembly. When they recognized their error in this, they turned from this verse to His saying: <<Seek help through Allah and be patient>> (اسْتَعِينُوا بِاللَّهِ واصْبِرُوا)—meaning, restrain your souls with Allah. When they separated from their kind (the High Assembly) through this verse, their spirits withered (ذبلت), though they had been in the freshness of bliss through associating with their kind. This is because they attached themselves to the One <<there is nothing like Him>> (لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ). They found no likeness-based affinity (مناسبة مثلية) between themselves and Him to attach to. Gnosis of Allah (المعرفة بالله) then told them: He, the Glorified, only addressed you with your own tongue, your own tone, and your own language, and what the people of that tongue, of whom you are one, have agreed upon. So return to the meaning of what He addressed you with, for He did not remove it from the reality of its signification. Do not seek the affinity to Him through your ignorance of that, for that Attribute with which He addressed you seeks you by its very Essence, because He described Himself with it. His Attributes can only exist through a special affinity from us to Him. If you attach yourself to that Attribute and adhere to it, you will necessarily attain Him. You will then know the form of your affinity to Him through a knowledge of tasting (علم ذوق) and Divine Theophany (تجل إلهي). Your wasting will increase until you become like the imagined point (النقطة المتوهمة), as one of them said:

> I have become, due to love-sickness for You,
> Like the imagined point (النقطة المتوهمة).

This is the point that has no existence except in the imagination (الوهم). This is their attribute in Wasting. This is confirmed by a report supported by Unveiling (كشف) that Israfil, peace be upon him, who is one of the highest celestial spirits, diminishes in himself seventy times every day due to the dominance of Allah’s Majesty over his heart, until he becomes like a small object (كالوضع), just as the arrogant ones among Allah’s servants will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection, diminished in their souls to the size of ants, in humiliation and insignificance. This is due to the arrogance and pride they displayed in the world. This is the attribute of their wasting in their spirits and bodies.

Another attribute of the Lovers is Consuming Love (الغرام), which is self-annihilation (الاستهلاك) in the Beloved through persistent grief (الكمد). The Exalted said: <<Indeed, its punishment is consuming>> (إِنَّ عَذابَها كانَ غَراماً)—meaning, destructive due to the persistence of witnessing the Beloved. The *gharīm* (debtor) is one who is bound by debt, and he is named *gharīm* for this reason. Its inverted form is *raghām* (dust), which is clinging to the earth, for *raghām* is dust. It is said, "May his nose be rubbed in the dust (رغم أنفه)," because the nose is the seat of honor, so it is countered by *raghām* in supplication, sticking it to the dust. Thus, *gharam* (Consuming Love) has the ruling of the inverted form (*raghām*) in the one consumed by it (المغرم). He is characterized by abasement (الذلة), because dust is the most abased of the abased. For this reason, the earth is described as submissive (ذلول) by way of hyperbole, because the abased tread upon it. Since Love adheres to the hearts of the Lovers, and Longing (الشوق) to the hearts of the longing ones, and sleeplessness to the souls of the sleepless, and every attribute of Love is characterized by it, the possessor of all these adherences is called *mughram* (consumed), and his attribute is called *gharam*. It is a name that encompasses all the attributes of Love that adhere to the Lover. There is no attribute of the Lover more comprehensive than *al-Gharam*.

Among the attributes of the Lovers is Longing (الشوق). It is a spiritual movement toward meeting the Beloved, and a natural, physical, sensory movement toward meeting the Beloved, if that Beloved is of his kind. When he meets the Beloved—whoever that Beloved may be—he finds stillness within the movement, and he becomes perplexed as to why that movement returns despite the meeting, and he sees it increasing. Fear overtakes him during the state of union (الوصلة). He finds that the fear is related to the expectation of separation (الفرقة), and he finds that the movement of longing seeks the perpetuation of the state of union. That is why it is aroused by the meeting, as was said concerning longing:

> The most intense longing occurs on a day
> When the dwellings draw near to the dwellings.

And another said concerning the fear in the state of union that we mentioned:

> I weep if they depart, out of longing for them,
> And I weep if they draw near, out of fear of separation.

This is the recompense of one who loves other than the Divine Essence (عينه) and places the existence of the essence of his beloved outside of himself. If he loved Allah, this would not be his state. The Lover of Allah does not fear separation. How can a thing separate from what is inseparable from it, which is in its grasp and never departs? And where his Beloved sees him, and He is <<nearer to him than the jugular vein>> (أَقْرَبُ إِلَيْهِ من حَبْلِ الْوَرِيدِ). And <<you threw not when you threw, but Allah threw>> (وما رَمَيْتَ إِذْ رَمَيْتَ ولكِنَّ الله رَمى). Where is separation when there is nothing in the cosmos but Him? Allah the Exalted says in the Hadith: "Whoever draws near to Me by a span, I draw near to him by a cubit."

Thus, my brother, you should know the worth of one who loves you for Allah or for himself. If the Real (الحق), despite His independence from the world, rushes to union with His servant when the servant loves Him, draws him near, makes his sitting place intimate, and makes him one of His special companions—then you are more deserving of this attribute. If a person loves you, he has granted you mastery over him and made himself a place for your command over him. If you are wise, you should know the worth of love and the worth of one who loves you, and you should hasten to unite with him, adopting the character of Allah (تخلقا بأخلاق الله) in His love. For whoever begins love with you, that is a favor (يد) from him to you that you can never fully repay. This is because everything he does out of love after his initial beginning with you is merely a result of that love with which he initiated loving you.

Among the attributes of the Lovers is Bewilderment (الهيام). They are the bewildered ones (المهيمون) who wander aimlessly (يهيمون على وجوههم) without intending a specific direction. The Lovers of Allah are more deserving of this attribute. For the one who loves a creature, if he wanders aimlessly, it is due to his restlessness and despair of uniting with his beloved. But the Lover of Allah is certain of union and knows that He, the Glorified, is not restricted or confined to a specific place to be sought therein, because the Reality of the Real (حقيقة الحق) rejects that. Therefore, He said: <<So wherever you turn, there is the Face of Allah>> (فَأَيْنَما تُوَلُّوا فَثَمَّ وَجْهُ الله). And He said: <<And He is with you wherever you are>> (وَهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ ما كُنْتُمْ). The Lover is bewildered in every valley and in every state, because his Beloved is the Real (الحق). He does not seek Him in a specific direction, but He discloses Himself (يتجلى له) in whatever direction he intends, in whatever state he may be. Thus, they are more entitled to the attribute of Bewilderment than the lovers of creatures. He, the Exalted, is the One witnessed by the Lovers from every essence (عين), the One mentioned by every tongue, and the One heard from every speaker. This is how the Gnostics (العارفون) know Him, and by this Reality (الحقيقة) He discloses Himself to the Lovers.

Among the attributes of the Lovers are Sighs (الزفرات). They are a burning fire of light (نار نور محرقة) that the heart is too constricted to bear, so they exit compressed due to the accumulation of grief (الكمد) that the Lover finds. A sound of intensely hot breathing is heard upon their exit, just as a sound is heard from fire, and that sound is called a sigh (*zafra*). This only occurs specifically in the natural body (الجسم الطبيعي). It may also occur in the embodied form (الصورة المتجسدة). For this reason, the embodied form derived from the abstract meaning (المعنى المجرد) is described, when that meaning appears in it, as having the form of anger or pleasure, like natural bodies, as the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said about himself: "I am only a human being; I become angry just as humans become angry, and I become pleased just as humans become pleased."

Since the Divine Presence (الجناب الإلهي), <<there is nothing like Him>> (لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ), has described Himself with pleasure (الرضى) and anger (الغضب) in these two attributes and their likes—attributes with which the Real described Himself—and since the world appeared from that Reality, we say that Allah, the Glorified, His Knowledge of Himself is His Knowledge of the World; it cannot be otherwise. Every reality and attribute that appears in the world has a Divine Origin (أصل إلهي) to which it returns. Were it not for that Divine Origin preserving its existence, it would not exist or subsist. Only the unique individuals (الآحاد) among the People of Allah know this, for it is a specialized knowledge. The Exalted said: <<And the wrath of Allah is upon him>> (وغَضِبَ الله عَلَيْهِ). And a report came that is more severe than this for one who understands Allah, which is what came in the authentic Hadith regarding the saying of the Prophets on the Day of Resurrection: "Indeed, Allah has become angry today with an anger He has never been angry with before, nor will He be angry with after it."

This is more severe than the previous, as His anger is characterized by origination and cessation. In that station, Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, says concerning those of his companions who changed after him: "Away! Away!" (سحقا سحقا). This is necessitated by the situation and the context, for the one in authority acts in his judgments according to the circumstances and contexts.

Among the attributes of the Lovers is Grief (الكمد). It is the most intense sorrow of the heart, accompanied by no tears, though its possessor sighs and groans frequently. It is a sorrow he finds within himself, not over something lost or a deficiency. This is the unknown sorrow (الحزن المجهول) that is one of the attributes of the Lovers, having no cause except Love specifically. It has no cure except union with the Beloved (وصال المحبوب). His preoccupation with the Beloved annihilates his sensation of grief. Even if the union with the Beloved is not a connection of essences (اتصال ذوات), the Beloved may be one who commands him, so the fulfillment of His commands and the joy derived from that preoccupies him from the grief. Grief is most intense when nothing occurs between him and the Beloved to distract him from himself. Grief is the only attribute of the Lover that vanishes with preoccupation.

The attributes of Love are very numerous, such as Regret (الأسف), Distraction (الوله), Stupefaction (البهت), Astonishment (الدهش), Bewilderment (الحيرة), Jealousy (الغيرة), Muteness (الخرس), Sickness (السقام), Restlessness (القلق), Quiescence (الخمود), Weeping (البكاء), Affliction (التبريح), Ecstasy (الوجد), and Sleeplessness (السهاد), and what the Lovers have mentioned in their poetry and discourse concerning this. Our discussion in this chapter concerns what is specific to Allah’s love for His servants and the servants’ love for Allah, and nothing else. Allah, the Glorified, has mentioned peoples whom He loves due to an attribute that exists in them, for which He loved them, just as He withdrew His love from others due to attributes that exist in them. He mentioned this in His Book and through the tongue of His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him.

End of the 113th part, concluding the 15th journey (سفر).

In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful.

### [That Allah Has Two Loves]

One aspect of this is following His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, in what he legislated. The Exalted said: <<Say, [O Muhammad], "If you should love Allah, then follow me, [so] Allah will love you">> (قُلْ إِنْ كُنْتُمْ تُحِبُّونَ الله فَاتَّبِعُونِي يُحْبِبْكُمُ الله).

Know that Allah has two loves (محبتين) or two relations (تعلقين). His love for His servants, which is the specificity of the first relation of the Will (إرادة التعلق الأول), is His loving them initially. By that love, He granted them success in following His Messengers, peace be upon all of them. Then, that following produced two relations of love for them, because the following occurred through two paths: one path is the performance of obligatory duties (الفرائض), and the other relation is the adherence to supererogatory acts (النوافل).

The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said, relating from his Lord, the Mighty and Majestic, that He said—and the Hadith continues: "My servant does not draw near to Me with anything more beloved to Me than the performance of what I have obligated upon him. And My servant continues to draw near to Me through supererogatory acts until I love him. When I love him, I am his hearing, his sight, his hand, and his supporter."

If the Real (الحق) is the hearing of the servant and strengthens him in supererogatory acts, what then of the love that comes from the Real to him through the performance of obligatory duties? It is that the Real wills with the will of this chosen servant (العبد المجتبى) and grants him control over the world as he wishes, by His primordial Will (مشيئته تعالى الأولية) which granted him success. This relation is thus subsumed under the first, which is His saying: <<And you do not will except that Allah wills>> (وما تَشاؤُنَ إِلَّا أَنْ يَشاءَ الله).

Every attribute that the Real mentioned as a reason for loving the one who possesses it—that attribute was only attained through following (الاتباع). For the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, established it as a Sunnah, and that is from Allah, for <<he does not speak from [his own] inclination>> (ما يَنْطِقُ عَنِ الْهَوى). And He acts through him and through us. He negated that the act belongs to him and to us, as some see it, which is His saying: <<I do not know what will be done with me or with you. I only follow what is revealed to me, and I am not but a clear warner>> (ما أَدْرِي ما يُفْعَلُ بِي ولا بِكُمْ إِنْ أَتَّبِعُ إِلَّا ما يُوحى‏ إِلَيَّ وما أَنَا إِلَّا نَذِيرٌ مُبِينٌ). This is His saying: <<The Messenger is only responsible for conveyance>> (ما عَلَى الرَّسُولِ إِلَّا الْبَلاغُ). The meaning of following is that we do what he tells us. If he says, "Follow me in my action," we follow him. If he does not say so, what is incumbent upon us is following what he says. The result of following what he commanded and forbade us, and stopping at his limits, is that we follow him in his actions in creation, which are called *karāma* (miracle/favor) and *āyah* (sign)—meaning, a sign of the truthfulness of the following. The Messengers are also followers, for he, peace be upon him, says: *I only follow what is revealed to me*. Thus, what appears through him of following in Allah’s action is a result of his following Allah’s commands, and it is a sign (*āyah*). For us, this is a *karāma*, which is action performed by spiritual resolve (الهمة) and concentration (التوجه) without direct physical involvement. Thus, extraordinary events (خرق العوائد) appear at the hand of this servant, which should only occur in that manner, without any apparent cause other than mere Will (الإرادة), except for Allah the Exalted. For if that action appeared through an established, apparent cause, it would not be of this category—like the flight of a bird due to an apparent cause, even though none holds it up except Allah (meaning, the Allah Who established the causes for its suspension in the air). When a human traverses the air and walks in it by mere Will, without an apparent, customary cause, he resembles the act of the Real in bringing things into existence by Will. This is the difference between it and its occurrence through causes. Its origin is the realization of following. The one followed in legislation is only Allah, and the one followed in action by Will is only Allah. All is by the care and Will of Allah. <<There is no god but He, the All-Mighty, the All-Wise>> (لا إِلهَ إِلَّا هُوَ الْعَزِيزُ الْحَكِيمُ).

Among this is His love, the Glorified, for the Repentant (التوابين). *Al-Tawwāb* (The Oft-Returning/Accepting of Repentance) is His Attribute and one of His Names, the Exalted. He says, the Mighty and Majestic: <<That Allah is the Oft-Returning>> (أَنَّ الله هُوَ التَّوَّابُ). Thus, He loves nothing but His Name and His Attribute, and He loves the servant for being characterized by it, but only if he is characterized by it according to the limit that the Real ascribed it to Himself. This is because the Real returns (يرجع) to His servant in every state the servant is in that distances him from Allah—which is called sin (*dhanb*), disobedience (*ma'ṣiya*), and transgression (*mukhālafa*). If the servant is established in the right of one of his peers or likes who has wronged him, and he returns to him with kindness and overlooks his offense, then that servant is the *Tawwāb* (Oft-Returning). He is not the one who returned to Allah, for it is not correct to return to Allah except for one who is ignorant that Allah is with him in every state. The Real only addressed those who were heedless of Allah being with them in every state with His saying: <<You will be returned to Allah>> (تُرْجَعُونَ فِيهِ إِلَى الله), just as He said: <<And He is with you wherever you are>> (وَهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ ما كُنْتُمْ) and <<We are nearer to him than the jugular vein>> (وَنَحْنُ أَقْرَبُ إِلَيْهِ من حَبْلِ الْوَرِيدِ). If you return to Him from the perspective of reckoning or questioning, that is truly a return from a state you are in to a state you are not in. Since all states are in the Hand of Allah, the return is ascribed to Allah in this manner. The one who returns to Allah only returns from transgression to conformity, and from disobedience to obedience. This is the meaning of the love for the Repentant. If you are one of the *Tawwābīn* (Oft-Returning) toward one who wronged you, then Allah will be *Tawwāb* (Oft-Returning) toward you regarding what you wronged Him in, returning to you with kindness. Thus, you should know the realities of matters and understand the meanings of Allah’s address to His servants, and distinguish between the Levels (المراتب), so that you may be among those who have Knowledge of Allah and what He has said. The mention of this love for the Repentant came immediately after the mention of the harm (الأذى) He placed in menstruation.

The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah loves every tried, repentant one (مفتن تواب)." Meaning, one who is tested (مختبر). Allah desires to test him with one of His servants who wrongs him, and he returns to them with kindness in response to their offense. He is the *Tawwāb*. It does not mean that Allah tests His servants with acts of disobedience—far be it from Allah that such a thing be ascribed to Him. Even though all acts belong to Allah from the perspective of their being acts, they are only acts of disobedience from the perspective of Allah’s ruling concerning them. All of Allah’s acts are good from the perspective of their being acts. Understand this.

Among this is His love for the Purified (المتطهرين). The Exalted said: <<And Allah loves the purified>> (ويُحِبُّ الْمُتَطَهِّرِينَ). Purification (التطهير) is an attribute of sanctification and transcendence (تقديس وتنزيه), and it is His Attribute, the Exalted. The servant’s purification is that he removes from himself every harm (أذى) that is unfitting for him to be seen in, even if it is praiseworthy relative to others, but legally reprehensible relative to him. If he purifies himself from that, Allah loves him—such as arrogance (الكبرياء), tyranny (الجبروت), boasting (التفخر), vanity (الخيلاء), and conceit (العجب). Some of these are attributes that do not enter the heart at all due to the Divine Seal (الطابع الإلهي) upon the hearts, which is His saying: <<Thus does Allah seal over every heart of an arrogant tyrant>> (كَذلِكَ يَطْبَعُ الله عَلى‏ كُلِّ قَلْبِ مُتَكَبِّرٍ جَبَّارٍ). Thus, arrogance and tyranny appear in his outward aspect toward those of his people who deserve it, either in his estimation and cunning, or in reality. Yet, in his heart, he is protected (*ma'ṣūm*) from that arrogance and tyranny, because he knows his helplessness, his abasement, and his poverty before all existing things. A flea bite pains him, and he needs the latrine to relieve the pain of urination and defecation, and he needs a piece of bread to ward off the pain of hunger. How can arrogance and tyranny be in the heart of one whose state is this every day and night? This is the Divine Seal upon his heart, so nothing of that enters it. As for the appearance of that on his outward aspect, that is accepted, but Allah has appointed stations for it where he appears with these descriptions without being reprehensible, and He has appointed stations where He censures him for it. Whoever purifies his essence (ذاته) from being seen with these attributes in inappropriate stations is *mutatahhir* (purified), and Allah loves him, just as He negated His love for every boastful, proud one (مختال فخور). For no one displays this attribute except one who is ignorant, and ignorance is reprehensible. That is why Allah forbade His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, from being ignorant, and He said to Noah, peace be upon him: <<Indeed, I advise you lest you be among the ignorant>> (إِنِّي أَعِظُكَ أَنْ تَكُونَ من الْجاهِلِينَ). He must either boast over his like or over his Lord and Creator. If he boasts over his like, he has boasted over himself, and a thing does not boast over itself. Thus, his boasting and vanity are ignorance. It is impossible for him to boast over his Creator, because he must either be a Gnostic of his Creator or ignorant that he has a Creator. If he knows Him and boasts over Him, he is ignorant of the attributes of perfection that should belong to his Creator. If he does not know Him, he is ignorant. Allah only hates him and does not love him because of his ignorance, since this (pride) only occurs outside its proper station due to his ignorance. Ignorance is death, and Knowledge (العلم) is life. This is His saying, the Exalted: <<Is he who was dead and We gave him life>> (أَ ومن كانَ مَيْتاً فَأَحْيَيْناهُ)—meaning, with Knowledge—<<and made for him a light by which to walk among the people>> (وَجَعَلْنا لَهُ نُوراً يَمْشِي به في النَّاسِ)—that is the light of faith and Unveiling (الكشف) that Allah revealed to him or bestowed upon him. Thus, the one purified from such attributes is beloved by Allah. Understand this.

### [That Allah Loves the Purifiers]

Among this is His love for the Purifiers (المطهرين). Allah the Exalted said: <<And Allah loves the purifiers>> (والله يُحِبُّ الْمُطَّهِّرِينَ). They are those who purify others just as they purified themselves. Their purification extends to others, and they stand in that capacity in the place of the Real (مقام الحق), acting as His deputies. For He is the Purifier in reality, the Preserver, the Protector, the Guardian, and the Forgiver. Whoever prevents his own essence and the essence of others from being characterized by what is reprehensible in Allah’s sight has protected, preserved, guarded, and veiled them from being characterized by such things. He is a purifier for them by teaching them the knowledge of what is fitting, so that the darkness and death of ignorance may flee from it by the light and life of knowledge. This will be in his balance on the Day of Resurrection and among the lights that run before him. He is beloved by Allah, singled out by the care of Divine Guardianship (ولاية إلهية) and Vicegerency (استخلاف). The guardians (الولاة) and vicegerents (الخلفاء) are among the near ones (المقربين) whom He has appointed over them, because they are a restricted place for those He appointed, unlike others. Every human is a guardian over his limbs and what is above that. Allah has informed him of the purification by which he purifies his subjects (رعاياه).

### [That Allah Loves the Patient]

Among this is His love for the Patient (الصابرين). This is His saying: <<And Allah loves the patient>> (والله يُحِبُّ الصَّابِرِينَ). They are those whom Allah tested, and they restrained their souls from complaining to anyone other than Allah, Who sent down this affliction upon them. <<They did not weaken for what struck them in the way of Allah>> (فَما وَهَنُوا لِما أَصابَهُمْ في سَبِيلِ الله), nor did they weaken in bearing it, because they bore it by Allah, even if it was difficult for them—it must be so, for if it were not difficult, it would not be an affliction. And they did not humble themselves (ما اسْتَكانُوا) to anyone other than Allah for its removal. They resorted to Allah for its removal, as the righteous servant said: <<Adversity has touched me, and You are the most merciful of the merciful>> (مَسَّنِيَ الضُّرُّ وأَنْتَ أَرْحَمُ الرَّاحِمِينَ). He raised his complaint to Him, not to others. Allah praised him, saying that He found him patient: <<What an excellent servant! Indeed, he was ever-returning [to Allah]>> (نِعْمَ الْعَبْدُ إِنَّهُ أَوَّابٌ), despite this complaint. This indicates that the patient one complains to Allah, not to others. Rather, this is incumbent upon him, because patience, if he does not complain to Allah, implies resistance to the Divine Compulsion (القهر الإلهي), which is bad manners with Allah. The Prophets, peace be upon them, are people of good manners and possess knowledge from Allah. You know that your patience was only by Allah, not from your own essence, nor from your own power and strength. For Allah says: <<And be patient; and your patience is not but through Allah>> (واصْبِرْ وما صَبْرُكَ إِلَّا بِاللَّهِ). With what, then, do you boast, when it is not yours? Allah only tests His servants so that they may resort to Him for its removal, and not resort to others for its removal. If they do that, they are among the patient ones, and he is beloved by Allah. *Al-Ṣabūr* (The Patient) is one of His descriptive Names (النعوتية). Thus, He loves only one who sees His robe upon him. There is a secret here: He established you in His station. Patience only occurs in the face of harm (أذى). We know that among His creation are those who harm Allah and His Messenger. He described them to us so that we may know them and repel that harm from Him, the Exalted, by fighting them or by teaching them if they are ignorant seekers of knowledge. He named Himself *Al-Ṣabūr* (The Patient). He informed us of the harm done to Him and made them known to us so that we may defend Him and repel the harm, while being characterized by patience, so that we may know that when we complain to Him about the affliction that has descended and ask Him to remove it from us, the name of patience does not depart from us, and His love does not depart from us, just as the Name *Al-Ṣabūr* did not depart from Him by informing us of those who harm Him so that we may defend Him.

It is reported in the *Ṣaḥīḥ* (Authentic Collection): "No one is more patient in the face of harm than Allah."

Pay attention to what we have alerted you to.

### [That Allah Loves the Thankful]

Among this is the love for the Thankful (الشاكرين). The Real described Himself in His Book as loving the Thankful. Gratitude (الشكر) is His favor, for He is *Shākir* (Appreciative) and *Alīm* (All-Knowing). He loves nothing from the servant except what is His own Attribute and description. Gratitude is only for blessings (النعم), not for affliction (البلاء), as some who lack knowledge of the Realities (الحقائق) claim. This is because the Exalted concealed His blessing within His vengeance (نقمته) and His vengeance within His blessing. This became confused for those who lack knowledge of the Realities—meaning, the realities of matters—so they imagined that one should be grateful for affliction, but this is incorrect. Consider one who drinks a disliked medicine. It is part of affliction, but it is an affliction only upon the one who is destroyed by it, which is the disease for which he used it. The pain is the enemy of this medicine; it seeks the pain. But when the affliction settled in this place that feels the pain, the contender who seeks to remove it from Existence (الوجود)—the medicine—arrived. The place found dislike for it, yet knew that within that disliked thing was a blessing, because it removes the pain. So he thanked Allah for the blessing contained within it and was patient with the dislike of using it, knowing that it seeks that pain to remove it. It only strives for the comfort of this place. Pay attention to this. For this reason, he was thankful. When he thanked Him for the hidden blessing in this disliked thing, He increased him in another blessing, which is wellness (*al-'āfiya*) and the removal of the disease, and his patience with the disliked medicine. Therefore, He said: <<If you are grateful, I will surely increase you>> (لَئِنْ شَكَرْتُمْ لَأَزِيدَنَّكُمْ). So He increased him in wellness.

Similarly, when the Real was harmed (أوذي الحق) and we strove to remove that harm by harming the offender or governing him until he retreated from the matter by which he was harming the Real—if we harmed this offender through fighting or similar means, that was for the Real like the patient drinking the disliked medicine at the moment, yet seeing it as a blessing because it removes the harmful matter. We say this because everything is from His Act, Decree, and Predetermination. Allah revealed to His Prophet David to build a house for Him (meaning the Holy House in Jerusalem). Every time he built it, it collapsed. His Lord revealed to him that it would not stand at his hands, for he had shed blood. David said: "O Lord, that was only in Your way." He said: "You spoke the truth, it was only in My way. Yet, are they not My servants? This House will only stand at the hand of one purified from the shedding of blood." David said: "O Lord, make it from me." Allah revealed to him that it would stand at the hand of his son Solomon, peace be upon him, and Solomon built it.

This is exactly what I alerted you to, if you pay attention. From this, you know the matter as it truly is: that the foundation of the Divine Command is always *He, not He* (هو لا هو). If you do not know it thus, you have not known it. <<You threw not when you threw, but Allah threw>> (وما رَمَيْتَ إِذْ رَمَيْتَ ولكِنَّ الله رَمى). This is exactly what we said: He, not He. Here, the minds of those who have not witnessed the Realities as they are become bewildered. When the servant removed this harm from the Divine Presence (جناب الحق)—even though it contained what the use of medicine contains—Allah thanked him for it. Gratitude seeks increase. So He sought from His servants, by His gratitude, that they increase Him, and they increased Him in action. This is the Prophet’s saying, peace be upon him: "Should I not be a grateful servant?"

So he increased in worship out of gratitude for Allah’s gratitude to him. The Real then increased him in guidance and success in the station of actions, even until the Hereafter, where there is neither action nor pain for the fortunate. As for the alert concerning the use of the disliked medicine in removing harm from Allah, the Real made it clear in His saying regarding the seizing of the soul of His believing servant. He described Himself, the Exalted, as disliking the servant’s distress, because the servant dislikes death, which is inevitable for him. He described Himself as disliking that. This is exactly the dislike of what the patient finds in drinking medicine, because the rank of Knowledge (العلم) dictates that. For the occurrence of the opposite of what is known is impossible. The existence of the world is necessary due to what the Divine Realities (الحقائق الإلهية) dictate. Where is possibility compared to necessity? Sharpen your heart and know: <<Indeed, Allah is Appreciative and All-Knowing>> (فَإِنَّ الله شاكِرٌ عَلِيمٌ). He followed His description of Himself with gratitude by describing Himself with Knowledge. Increase your action, and you will have recompensed your Lord for His gratitude to you for what you did for Him. That action is fasting, for it is for Him, and repelling harm from Him. This is His saying: "Did you show loyalty for My sake, or enmity for My sake?" And His saying: "My love is incumbent upon those who love one another for My sake, those who visit one another for My sake, those who sit together for My sake, and those who spend on one another for My sake."

May Allah make us among those upon whom He bestowed favor, so they saw Allah’s blessing upon them in every state and were grateful.

### [That Allah Loves the Doers of Good]

Among this is the love for the Doers of Good (المحسنين). This is His saying: <<And Allah loves the doers of good>> (والله يُحِبُّ الْمُحْسِنِينَ). *Iḥsān* (Doing Good/Excellence) is His Attribute, and He is *Al-Muḥsin* (The Doer of Good), *Al-Mujammil* (The Beautifier). He loves His Attribute, which is manifest in His Essence. The *Iḥsān* by which the servant is called a *Muḥsin* is that he worships Allah *as if he sees Him* (كأنه يراه)—meaning, he worships Him based on Witnessing (المشاهدة). Allah’s *Iḥsān* is the station of His seeing His servants in their movements and actions. This is His saying: <<Indeed, He is over all things a Witness>> (أَنَّهُ عَلى‏ كُلِّ شَيْ‏ءٍ شَهِيدٌ). And <<He is with you wherever you are>> (وَهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ ما كُنْتُمْ). His witnessing of everything is His *Iḥsān*, for by His witnessing, He preserves it from destruction. Every state the servant transitions through is from Allah’s *Iḥsān*, since He, the Exalted, is the One Who transitions him. For this reason, bestowal of favor (*al-in'ām*) is called *Iḥsān*. For no one bestows favor upon you intentionally except one who knows you, and one whose knowledge is his very seeing is a *Muḥsin* perpetually, for He sees you perpetually because He knows you always. *Iḥsān* in the Sacred Law is nothing but this. The Prophet said to him (Gabriel): "If you do not see Him, then indeed, He sees you." Meaning, if you do not achieve *Iḥsān* (excellence in worship), then He is *Al-Muḥsin* (the Excellent One). This teaching by the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to Gabriel in the presence of the Companions is from the category of their saying: "I mean you, so listen, O neighbor." The one addressed is not the intended recipient of that knowledge, for he already knows it. The intended recipients are those listeners who were present. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, explained it thus in this Hadith, saying: "This is Gabriel, who came to teach the people their religion."

Among this is the love for those who fight in the way of Allah with a specific description. The Exalted said: <<Indeed, Allah loves those who fight in His cause in a row as though they are a structure joined firmly>> (إِنَّ الله يُحِبُّ الَّذِينَ يُقاتِلُونَ في سَبِيلِهِ صَفًّا كَأَنَّهُمْ بُنْيانٌ مَرْصُوصٌ). He means that no gap should enter it. For gaps in the rows are the paths of the devils, and the Path (الطريق) is one, which is the Way of Allah (سبيل الله). If this apparent line (الخط الظاهر) of points is cut and not joined firmly, the existence of the line does not appear. The goal is the existence of the line (الحظ). This is the meaning of firm joining (*raṣṣ*) for the existence of the Way of Allah. Whoever does not strive for the manifestation of the Way of Allah is not one of the People of Allah. Similarly, the rows of those praying are not in the Way of Allah until they connect and the people join firmly in them. At that point, the Way of Allah appears in its essence. Whoever does not do this and introduces a gap is one who strives to cut off the Way of Allah and remove it from Existence (الوجود). Allah desired His servants in such a matter to be among the creators (الخالقين). That is why He said: <<So blessed is Allah, the best of creators>> (فَتَبارَكَ الله أَحْسَنُ الْخالِقِينَ). The Way (السبيل) can only be like this: like a line existing from adjacent points between which there is no empty space without a point. At that point, the form of the line appears. Likewise, the row: the Way of Allah does not appear in it until the people join firmly. He seeks Multiplicity (الكثرة), and in the Divine Presence (جناب الله), it is the firm joining of His Names, the Blessed and Exalted, from which the Way of Creation (سبيل الخلق) appears. Thus, *Al-Ḥayy* (The Living) is next to *Al-'Alīm* (The All-Knowing), and there is no gap between them for another Name. And next to it is *Al-Murīd* (The Willing), and next to it is *Al-Qā'il* (The Speaker), and next to it is *Al-Qādir* (The Powerful), and next to it is *Al-Ḥakam* (The Judge), and next to it is *Al-Muqīt* (The Maintainer), and next to it is *Al-Muqsiṭ* (The Equitable), and next to it is *Al-Mudabbir* (The Planner), and next to it is *Al-Mufaṣṣil* (The Distinguisher), and next to it is *Al-Rāziq* (The Provider), and next to it is *Al-Muḥyī* (The Giver of Life). This is how the row of Divine Names is formed for the creation of the Way of Creation, whose existence depends on this firm joining. When this Way appears—and it is not an addition to the firm joining of these Names—Creation is characterized by these Names, because they are in their state of firm joining through the path of Creation. They remain manifest in Creation and are only understood thus. The world is Living, Knowing, Willing, Speaking, Powerful, Judging, Maintaining, Equitable, Planning, Distinguishing. Thus, to the rest of the Divine Names. This is what is expressed in the Path as "adopting the character of the Names" (التخلق بالأسماء). They appear in the servant just as they appear in the creation of the Straight Path (الطريق المستقيم) through their firm joining. If a gap enters them in existence, the Way of Allah vanishes, and the ways of the devils appear, which penetrate the gaps in the rows, as reported in the Hadith. Pay attention to what I have alerted you to.

If the servant stands in the station of the Names of the Real in the creation of creation, and fights the enemies—who are like the devils that penetrate the gaps in the row—with this attribute, they will necessarily be victorious, because there remains no gap for the enemy to enter through. Allah loved those whose attribute is this. Likewise, the human being alone is a row in everything he is involved in motion. All his movements are for Allah, with nothing for other than Allah penetrating them. No one can resist him. For the enemies’ eyes are fixed upon him, watching his movements and actions, hoping to find a gap through which they can enter and cut him off from Allah by cutting off the Way of Allah. Every line (خط) of action is a collection of Divine Names and praiseworthy Attributes. Actions are numerous, so the matter becomes dense and great, and the forms of compounds appear in the world. Since two or more lines form a surface, and two or more surfaces form a body (جسم), every body is compounded of eight things, which is the form of perfection that appeared from an Essence (ذات) and seven Attributes (صفات). The limit of composition is the body, and there is no rank beyond it. It stands upon eight without dispute among all. What is added to this is merely *ajsam* (more bodies)—meaning, more surfaces. If it has more surfaces, it has more lines. If it has more lines, it has more points. It has not increased beyond what the body—which is the first of bodies—is composed of, except for the first matter that preceded it, or by which the first body existed. Whoever joins firmly in an attribute is a creator. The Exalted said: <<So blessed is Allah, the best of creators>> (فَتَبارَكَ الله أَحْسَنُ الْخالِقِينَ). He affirmed this description for them and made Himself the best, not denying His precedence in that, for without Him, the essences of these creators would not have appeared. So affirm what Allah affirmed, and do not remove it, lest you be deprived of the benefit of knowledge by conforming to the Real, and thus be among the transgressors and the ignorant. Whoever possesses this attribute is beloved by Allah, the Exalted. When one is beloved, no one knows what his lover gives him, for he gives for his own sake.

A question arises here that needs clarification: Allah loves His friends (أولياءه), and a lover does not pain his beloved. Yet, no one suffers more pain or affliction in the world than Allah’s friends, His Messengers, His Prophets, and their followers, who are protected and assisted in their following. By what reality did they deserve this affliction despite being beloved? We say that Allah said: <<He loves them and they love Him>> (يُحِبُّهُمْ ويُحِبُّونَهُ). Affliction only ever occurs with a claim (دعوى). Whoever does not claim a matter is not tested by the establishment of proof for the truthfulness of his claim. Were it not for the claim, the affliction would not occur. However, the Messenger is not required to provide proof, for he did not claim. For this reason, it is said that the negator is not required to establish proof. But the matter is not so; rather, proof is required of him if he claims the negation. If he claims negation in a matter, that is the affirmation of the very essence of the claim, so the negator is required to establish proof from the perspective of his claim, because he is an affirmer. When Allah loved those of His servants whom He loved, He provided them with His love without them knowing it. They found in their souls a love for Allah, so they claimed that they were Lovers of Allah. Allah afflicted them because they were claimants of love, and He bestowed favor upon them because they were beloved. His favor upon them is proof of His love for them. <<To Allah belongs the conclusive argument>> (فَلِلَّهِ الْحُجَّةُ الْبالِغَةُ). And His testing them is due to their claim of loving Him. For this reason, Allah tested His beloved ones among creation. <<And Allah speaks the truth, and He guides to the way>> (والله يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ).

### [That Allah Loves Beauty]

Among this is the love for Beauty (الجمال). It is a Divine Attribute (نعت إلهي). It is established in the *Ṣaḥīḥ* (Authentic Collection) that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah is Beautiful (جميل) and loves Beauty."

By His saying "Beautiful," He alerted us to love Him. We are divided into two groups regarding this. Some of us looked at the beauty of perfection, which is the beauty of wisdom (الحكمة), and loved it in everything, because everything is perfected and is the handiwork of a Wise One. Others, whose rank did not reach this, possess no knowledge of Beauty except this restricted beauty (الجمال المقيد) that is limited to a specific purpose. In the Sacred Law, this is the station of His saying: *Worship Allah as if you see Him*.

The particle *kāf* (as if) denotes similarity of attribute. This person who did not reach a greater understanding than this restricted beauty confined himself to it, just as he was confined to the *Qibla* (direction of prayer). He loves Him for His Beauty, and there is no blame upon him for that, for he has performed a prescribed act according to his capacity, and <<Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity>> (لا يُكَلِّفُ الله نَفْساً إِلَّا وُسْعَها). It remains for us to discuss His love, the Exalted, for Beauty.

### [That Allah Loves Beauty]

Know that Allah created the World (العالم) in the utmost perfection and precision, as Imam Abu Hamid al-Ghazali said: "There remains nothing more wondrous in possibility than this World." He informed us that He created Adam upon His form (صورته), and the human being is the totality of the World. His Knowledge of the World, the Exalted, was only His Knowledge of Himself, since there was nothing in Existence (الوجود) but Him. Therefore, the World must be upon His form. When He manifested it in its essence (عينه), it was His locus of manifestation (مجلاه). He saw nothing in it but His Beauty, so He loved Beauty. The World is the Beauty of Allah. He is the Beautiful Who loves Beauty. Whoever loves the World with this perspective has loved it with the love of Allah, and he has loved nothing but the Beauty of Allah. For the beauty of the handiwork is not ascribed to the handiwork itself, but rather to its Maker. Thus, the beauty of the World is the Beauty of Allah. The form of His Beauty—I mean the beauty of things—is subtle. For example, consider two forms in the world—say, two persons whom nature loves, two maidens or two youths. They share the reality of humanity, so they are alike. The perfection of the form consists of the perfection of the limbs and organs, and the soundness of the whole and the parts from defects and ailments.
