One of them is characterized by beauty, and everyone who sees her loves her. The other is characterized by ugliness, and everyone who sees her dislikes her. What, then, is the Beauty upon which the name of Beauty was applied, such that everyone who saw it loved it? We entrust you with the knowledge of that to your own soul and contemplation. This is when the love of a person occurs solely from mere sight, not after companionship and association. Contemplate this, and you will, God willing, stumble upon the very essence of the matter in the description of the Real as Beautiful and His love for Beauty, despite His creation of the disliked, the harmful, and what does not suit temperaments or accord with purposes. We have mentioned a portion of the attributes that Allah loves in those who are characterized by them, and they are very numerous. We have alerted you through what we mentioned to their source and how the human being acts in relation to them. Now, we shall mention a portion of the attributes of Love that the Lover should possess, God willing, by which he is called a Lover. They are like the definitions (حدود) of Love.

Among these is that he is described as: one slain (مقتول), a familiar traveler toward Him by His Names, a flyer, perpetually sleepless, concealing grief, desiring to depart from the world to meet his Beloved, weary of the company of whatever intervenes between him and meeting his Beloved, frequently sighing, finding comfort in the speech and remembrance of his Beloved by reciting His remembrance, conforming to the desires of his Beloved, fearful of abandoning reverence in performing service, deeming much of his own effort little in the right of his Lord, and deeming little from his Beloved much, embracing the obedience of his Beloved and shunning disobedience to Him, entirely departed from himself, not seeking blood-money for his slaying, patient in the face of adversity that nature recoils from, due to what his Beloved has charged him with in managing it, bewildered in heart (هائم القلب), preferring his Beloved over every companion, annihilation (محو) in affirmation, having prepared his soul for whatever his Beloved wills for him, intermingled in attributes, having no self with Him—all of him belongs to Him, reproaching his own soul concerning the right of his Beloved, finding pleasure in astonishment, having exceeded the limits after preserving them, jealous over his Beloved from himself, his love governing him according to the measure of his intellect, his wound is healed by the Compeller (جبار), his love accepts neither increase from the Beloved’s kindness nor decrease from His harshness, forgetful of his own share and the share of his Beloved, not required to adhere to manners, stripped of attributes (مخلوع النعوت), unknown by names, as if he asks but is not asking, not distinguishing between union and separation, bewildered (هيمان), passionately devoted (متيم) in intimacy, possessing confusion, outside of measure, saying of himself that he is the very essence of his Beloved (عين محبوبه), consumed (مصطلم), exhausted (مجهود), not saying to his Beloved, "Why did You do this or say that?", his veil torn (مهتوك الستر), his secret public, the scandal of the age, not knowing concealment, not knowing that he is a lover, intensely longing but not knowing for whom, possessing great ecstasy but not knowing in whom, his Beloved is not distinct to him, joyful and sorrowful, described by opposites, his station is muteness (الخرس), his state translates for him, not desiring compensation, intoxicated and never sobering up, watchful, striving for His pleasure, preferring mercy and compassion for the Beloved in what He gives, a witness to his state, possessing sorrows, whenever he finishes, he exerts himself (نصب), not knowing fatigue, his spirit is a gift and his body is a mount, knowing nothing except what is in the essence of his Beloved, content of eye, speaking only with His speech. They are the ones called the Bearers of the Quran, because the Lovers, by encompassing all attributes, are the very essence of the Quran, just as Aisha said when asked about the character of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: "His character was the Quran."

[The answer] was nothing other than this. Dhū al-Nūn was asked who the bearers of the Qur'an were. He replied: They are those upon whom the clouds of sorrow have rained down, who have exhausted their knees and bodies, who have clothed themselves in fear and grief, who have drunk from the cup of certainty (اليقين), and who have disciplined their souls with the discipline of those who are certain. The delight of their eyes (قرة أعينهم) was found in what was little and sufficient, what reached its goal and covered and concealed. They applied kohl to their eyes with wakefulness, lowered them from looking [at the world], bound them to contemplation (العبر), and filled them with reflection (الفكر). They stood through their nights sleeplessly, and their eyes flowed continuously with tears. They accompanied the Qur'an with emaciated bodies, withered lips, flowing tears, and deadly sighs. This state stood between them and the bliss of the blissful, and the ultimate hopes of the desirous. Their tears flowed profusely from [Allah's] threat, and their forelocks turned gray from His warning. The roaring of the Fire was beneath their feet, and His threat was fixed before their hearts.

Among the most subtle stories we have related concerning the state of the lover (المحب) is that of a person among the lovers who entered upon one of the Shaykhs. The Shaykh spoke to him about love (المحبة). That person continued to dissolve, melt, and flow with sweat until his entire body disintegrated and became a pool of water on the mat before the Shaykh; he had completely melted. His companion entered and saw no one with the Shaykh. He asked him, "Where is so-and-so?" The Shaykh replied, "He is here," pointing to the water, and described his state. This is a strange dissolution and a wondrous transformation, as he did not cease to shed his density until he returned to water. He was first alive *by* water, and now he returned to *give life* to everything, for Allah said: <<وَجَعَلْنَا مِنَ الْمَاءِ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ حَيٍّ>> (And We made from water every living thing). The lover, according to this, is one by whom everything lives.

My father, may Allah have mercy on him, or my uncle—I do not know which of them informed me—told me that he saw a hunter who had caught a turtle dove, a pigeon of the thicket. Its mate, a male, came, and when he saw her slaughtered by the hunter, he flew high into the air, circling until he ascended, while we watched him, until he almost disappeared from our sight. Then he folded his wings, wrapped himself in them as in a shroud, turned his head toward the ground, and descended with a resounding crash until he fell upon her, dying instantly while we watched. This is the act of a bird. O lover, where is your claim regarding the love of your Master?

Muhammad ibn Muhammad narrated to us, from Hibat al-Rahman, from Abū al-Qasim ibn Hawāzin, who said: I heard Muhammad ibn al-Husayn say: I heard Ahmad ibn Ali say: I heard Ibrāhīm ibn Fātik say: I heard Sumnūn while he was sitting in the mosque speaking about love (المحبة). A small bird came near him, then approached, and continued to draw closer until it perched on his hand. Then it struck the ground with its beak until blood flowed from it, and it died. This is the effect of love upon a bird. Allah made it understand the words of this Shaykh, so the spiritual state (الحال) overwhelmed it, and the sovereignty of love ruled over it, serving as an admonition to those present and a proof against the pretenders.

Indeed, Allah has granted us an abundant share of it, yet He strengthened us against it. By Allah, I find within me a love (الحب) that, if placed in my thought upon the heavens, they would split asunder; upon the stars, they would be scattered; and upon the mountains, they would be moved. This is my tasting (ذوقي) of it, but the Real (الحق) strengthened me in it with the strength of His inheritors, who are the chiefs of the lovers. I have seen wonders within myself concerning it that no describer can reach. Love is according to the degree of the Theophany (التجلي), and the Theophany is according to the degree of Gnosis (المعرفة). Whoever dissolves in it and upon whom its rulings appear—that is natural love (المحبة الطبيعية). But the love of the Gnostics (محبة العارفين) has no effect upon the witnessed world, for Gnosis erases its effects due to a secret it imparts, which only the Gnostics know. Thus, the Gnostic lover is alive and does not die, a spirit (روح) stripped bare, of whom Nature (الطبيعة) has no knowledge concerning the love he bears. His love is Divine (إلهي), and his yearning is Lordly (رباني), supported by the Name al-Quddūs (The Holy) against the influence of perceptible speech. The proof of this is the one who dissolved until he became water. Had he not possessed [natural] love, this would not have been his state. He was a lover, yet he did not dissolve until he heard the Shaykh’s speech, which stirred his hidden love, and what happened, happened. Love that has no ruling over the lover until the speech of a speaker excites it is natural love, because it is Nature that accepts transformation (الاستحالة) and excitation. He was described as having love before the Shaykh’s speech, yet he did not undergo this dissolution that turned him into water after he had been bone, flesh, and sinew. Had his love been Divine, the words of letters would not have affected him, nor would these circumstances have shaken his spirituality. He felt shame regarding his claim of love, and the fire of shame arose in his heart, which continued to dissolve him until he became as related. Therefore, only the possessor of natural love is subject to change in the fixed entities (الأعيان) and transition through the phases of the cosmos (الأكوان). This is the criterion (الفرقان) between the spiritual Divine love (الحب الروحاني الإلهي) and natural love (الحب الطبيعي). Spiritual love is intermediate between Divine love and natural love: in what is Divine, his essence (عينه) remains; in what is natural, the state changes upon him but does not annihilate him. Annihilation (الفناء) is perpetual from the side of natural love, and the subsistence of the essence (بقاء العين) is from the side of Divine love.

When Gabriel (جبريل) had spiritual love (حبه روحانيا)—and he is a spirit (روح) with a face turned toward Nature (الطبيعة) by virtue of his corporeality—because natural bodies external to the elements do not transform, unlike elemental bodies which do transform because they originate from transformable principles, and Nature itself does not transform because the realities (الحقائق) do not invert their essences (أعيانها)—Gabriel swooned, but the very substance of his body did not dissolve, as happened to the subject of the anecdote. He swooned due to the natural love within him, but his essence remained due to his Divine love. Thus, the Divine lover is a spirit without a body, the natural lover is a body without a spirit, and the spiritual lover possesses both body and spirit. The elemental natural lover lacks a spirit to preserve him from transformation. Therefore, speech concerning love affects the natural lover, has no effect on the lover with Divine love, and has some effect on the lover with spiritual love.

Muhammad ibn Ismā‘īl al-Yamanī narrated to us in Mecca, saying: ‘Abd al-Rahmān ibn ‘Alī narrated to us, saying: Abū Bakr ibn Habīb al-‘Āmirī informed us, saying: ‘Alī ibn Abī Sādiq informed us, saying: Abū ‘Abd Allāh ibn Bākūyah al-Shīrāzī informed us, saying: Bakrān ibn Ahmad informed us, saying: I heard Yūsuf ibn al-Husayn say: I was sitting before Dhū al-Nūn, and people were around him. He was speaking to them, and the people were weeping, but a youth was laughing. Dhū al-Nūn said to him, "What is the matter with you, young man? The people are weeping, and you are laughing." The youth began to recite:

> All of them worship out of fear of the Fire, / And they see salvation as a great portion.
> I have no opinion regarding Paradise or the Fire; / I seek no substitute for my love.

He was asked, "But what will you do if He casts you out?" He replied:

> If I find no union (وصل) from Love, / I will seek a dwelling and resting place in the Fire.
> Then I will disturb its inhabitants with my weeping, / Morning and evening in its depths.
> O company of polytheists, wail over me! / I am a servant who answered a Glorious Master.
> If I am not truthful in what I have claimed, / Then let Him repay me with severe torment.

I personally served a woman among the Gnostic lovers (المحبات العارفات) in Seville named Fāṭima bint Ibn al-Muthannā al-Qurṭubī. I served her for years, and at the time of my service, she was over ninety-five years old. I used to be ashamed to look at her face, even at that age, because of the redness of her cheeks, the beauty of her grace, and her loveliness; you would think she was a girl of fourteen due to her delicacy and refinement. She had a spiritual state (حال) with Allah and preferred me over all others who served her like me. She would say, "I have never seen anyone like so-and-so. When he enters upon me, he enters with his entirety, leaving nothing outside of me. And when he leaves me, he leaves with his entirety, leaving nothing of himself with me." I heard her say, "I wonder at one who claims he loves Allah yet does not rejoice in Him, while He is his witnessed reality (مشهوده), His eye looking upon him in every eye, never absent from him for the blink of an eye. How can these weeping people claim His love and weep? Do they not feel shame, when His proximity is multiplied beyond the proximity of those who draw near to Him? The lover is the closest of people to Him; He is his witnessed reality. So, over whom does he weep? This is truly astonishing." Then she would say to me, "My son, what do you say about what I am saying?" I would reply, "Mother, the word is your word." She said, "By Allah, I am astonished. My Beloved (حبيبي) gave me the Opening Chapter of the Book (Fātiḥat al-Kitāb) to serve me, and by Allah, it has never distracted me from Him." On that day, I understood the station (مقام) of this woman when she said that the Fātiḥat al-Kitāb served her. While we were sitting, a woman entered and said to me, "Brother, my husband is in Jerez de la Frontera (Shuraysh Shadhūnah), and I have been informed that he is marrying [another woman] there. What do you think?" I asked her, "Do you want him to return?" She said, "Yes." I turned my face to the old woman and said, "Mother, do you not hear what this woman is saying?" She replied, "What do you want, my son?" I said, "The fulfillment of her need at this moment, and my need is that her husband returns." She said, "Hearing and obedience. I will send the Fātiḥat al-Kitāb to him and instruct it to bring this woman’s husband to me." She then began the Fātiḥat al-Kitāb, reciting it, and I recited with her. I understood her station during her recitation of the Fātiḥah, which was that through her recitation, she created an embodied, aerial form (صورة مجسدة هوائية) of it, and then dispatched it. When she created the form, I heard her say to it, "O Fātiḥat al-Kitāb, go to Jerez and bring this woman’s husband to me, and do not leave him until you bring him." He did not delay longer than the time it took to travel the distance of his arrival, and he reached his family. She used to play the tambourine and rejoice. When I asked her about this, she would say to me, "I rejoice in Him because He cared for me, made me one of His saints (أوليائه), and chose me for Himself. Who am I that this Master should choose me over others of my kind? By the honor of my Companion, He is jealous over me with a jealousy I cannot describe. I never turn to anything, relying upon it out of heedlessness, but He afflicts me with a calamity concerning that thing to which I turned." Then she showed me wonders concerning this. I continued to serve her personally and built her a house of reeds with my own hands, the size of her stature. She remained in it until she passed away. She used to say to me, "I am your Divine Mother, and the light of your earthly mother. When my mother came to visit her, she would say to her, "O Nūr (Light), this is my son, and he is your father, so honor him and do not disobey him."

Yūnus ibn Yahyā informed us in Mecca in the year 599 AH, saying: Abū Bakr ibn al-Ghazāl informed us, saying: Abū al-Faḍl ibn Ahmad informed us, saying: Ahmad ibn ‘Abd Allāh informed us, saying: ‘Uthmān ibn Muhammad al-‘Uthmānī narrated to us, saying: Muhammad ibn Ibrāhīm al-Mudhakkir narrated to us, saying: Muhammad ibn Yazīd narrated to us, saying: I heard Dhū al-Nūn say: I went out performing the Hajj to the Sacred House of Allah. While I was circumambulating, I saw a person clinging to the curtains of the Ka‘ba, weeping and saying in his weeping: "I concealed my affliction from all but You, and I revealed my secret to You. I occupied myself with You away from all others. I wonder at one who knows You, how he can forget You, and at one who tastes Your love, how he can endure separation from You." Then he began to recite:

> You made me taste the flavor of union (الوصال), so You increased my / Yearning for You, which permeates my depths.

Then he turned to address himself, saying: "He gave you respite, yet you did not heed. He covered your faults, yet you felt no shame. He stripped you of the sweetness of intimate converse (المناجاة), yet you did not care." Then he said: "My Beloved, why is it that when I stand before You, You cast drowsiness upon me and deny me the sweetness of intimate converse? Why is the delight of my eye a mere moment?" Then he began to recite:

> You terrified my heart with separation (الفراق), and I found / Nothing more bitter or painful than separation.
> Separation is enough, in that it separates us, / And how often have I been terrified by it!

Dhū al-Nūn said: I approached him, and behold, it was a woman.

(An anecdote) A lover who revealed the secret of his Beloved. Muhammad ibn Ismā‘īl ibn Abī al-Sayf narrated to us, saying: ‘Abd al-Rahmān ibn ‘Alī narrated to us, saying: The two Muhammads, Ibn Nāṣir and Ibn ‘Abd al-Bāqī, informed us, and Yūnus ibn Yahyā also narrated to me from both of them, saying: Hamd ibn Ahmad informed us, saying: Ahmad ibn ‘Abd Allāh informed us, saying: Ahmad ibn Muhammad al-Mutawakkilī narrated to us, saying: Ahmad ibn ‘Alī ibn Thābit narrated to us, saying: ‘Alī ibn al-Qāsim al-Shāhid said: I heard Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn ‘Īsā al-Rāzī say: I heard Yūsuf ibn al-Husayn say: A youth used to attend the assembly of Dhū al-Nūn al-Miṣrī for a period, then he was absent for a time. He later attended, his color pale, his body emaciated, and the signs of worship and striving (الاجتهاد) apparent upon him. Dhū al-Nūn said to him, "Young man, what gifts has your service to your Master and your striving earned you, which He has bestowed upon you and singled you out with?" The youth replied, "O Master, have you ever seen a servant whom his Master chose from among His slaves, singled him out, gave him the keys to the treasuries, and then confided a secret to him—is it proper for him to divulge that secret?" Then he began to recite:

> Whoever is confided in, yet reveals the secret, striving [to speak], / They will not trust him with secrets as long as he lives.
> They distance him, so he is not blessed by their proximity, / And they exchange intimacy (الإيناس) for estrangement (إيحاشا).
> They do not choose one who divulges even part of their secret; / Far be their affection from such a thing!

He means that it is not proper for the lover to strive to reveal the Beloved’s secret; rather, he awaits the command of his Beloved. If He commands him to divulge it, he divulges it; otherwise, the principle is concealment. Indeed, Allah granted me one of His secrets in the city of Fez in the year 594 AH, and I divulged it, for I did not know that it was one of the secrets that should not be divulged. I was reproached for it by the Beloved. I had no answer except silence, except that I said to Him, "You take charge of the matter concerning those to whom I entrusted it, if You have jealousy (غيرة) over it, for You are able, and I am not." I had entrusted it to about eighteen men. He said to me, "I will take charge of that." Then He informed me that He had drawn it out of their breasts and stripped it from them while I was in Ceuta. I said to my companion, ‘Abd Allāh the servant, "Allah has informed me that He has done such-and-such. Let us travel to the city of Fez so that we may see what He mentioned to me concerning this." So I traveled. When that group came to me, I found that Allah had stripped them of it and extracted it from their breasts. They asked me about it, and I remained silent concerning them. This is one of the most astonishing things that has happened to me in this chapter. Praise be to Allah, for He did not punish me with the estrangement (الوحشة) that this youth mentioned to Dhū al-Nūn. Since the path of Allah is based on tasting (ذوقا), this youth imagined that the way the Real dealt with him was the way He deals with all creation. His tasting is correct, but his judgment concerning Allah based on it is not correct. This happens frequently on the Path, except among the Verifiers (المحققين), for such a thing does not happen to them due to their knowledge of the levels (مراتب) of things and their realities (حقائقها), and this is a science difficult to attain.

We related from Dhū al-Nūn, from the narration of Muhammad ibn Yazīd, from Dhū al-Nūn, who said: I said to a woman, "When do sorrows encompass the heart of the lover?" She replied, "When he dwells near remembrance (التذكار) and is present with yearning (الشوق). O Dhū al-Nūn, do you not know that yearning causes sickness, and the renewal of remembrance causes grief?" Then she recited:

> I did not taste the sweet flavor of Your union / Until my love for mankind vanished from me.

He said: I replied to her:

> Excellent is the lover when his union increases, / And his love rises following union.

She said, "You have hurt me! You have hurt me! Do you not know that one cannot reach Him except by abandoning all besides Him?" I said, "If she had said such a thing to me, I would have replied to her, 'If that were the case, then...'"

More than one person narrated to us, including Ibn Abī al-Sayf, from ‘Abd al-Rahmān ibn ‘Alī, who said: Ibrāhīm ibn Dīnār informed us, saying: Ismā‘īl ibn Muhammad narrated to us, saying: ‘Abd al-‘Azīz ibn Ahmad informed us, saying: Abū al-Shaykh ‘Abd Allāh ibn Muhammad informed me, saying: I heard Abū Sa‘īd al-Thaqafī relate from Dhū al-Nūn, who said: I was performing the circumambulation when I heard a sorrowful voice. Behold, a young woman was clinging to the curtains of the Ka‘ba, saying:

> You know, O my Beloved, / O my Beloved, You know.
> The emaciation of my body and my spirit / Reveal my secret.
> O my Precious One, I have concealed love / Until my breast became constricted.

Dhū al-Nūn said: What I heard grieved me so much that I sobbed and wept. She said, "My God, my Master, and my Lord, by Your love for me, forgive me!" This seemed enormous to me, and I said, "O girl, is it not enough for you to say, 'By my love for You,' that you must say, 'By Your love for me'?" She replied, "Away from me, O Dhū al-Nūn! Do you not know that Allah has a people whom He loves before they love Him? Have you not heard Allah say: <<فَسَوْفَ يَأْتِي اللَّهُ بِقَوْمٍ يُحِبُّهُمْ وَيُحِبُّونَهُ>> (Then Allah will bring forth a people whom He loves and who love Him)? His love for them preceded their love for Him." I asked, "How did you know that I am Dhū al-Nūn?" She said, "O idle one, hearts have traversed the field of secrets (ميدان الأسرار), and thus I knew you." Then she said, "Look behind you." I turned my face, and I do not know whether the sky snatched her away or the earth swallowed her up. I said: The account of this girl is close to the state of Moses (Mūsā), peace be upon him, with his Lord: "Look at the mountain."

Allah the Exalted has fields (ميادين) which are all called the fields of love (ميادين المحبة). Then each field is distinguished by a name from the attributes of love, such as the field of ecstasy (الوجد) and the field of yearning (الشوق). Every spiritual state (حال) that involves traversing and movement has a field; this is a universal principle. Similarly, Gnosis (المعارف) also has Presences (حضرات) and assemblies. They are not called fields unless the Glorified One makes you witness, in your gnosis of Him, differentiation within the essences of the cosmos (أعيان الأكوان). If you witness that He is the manifest Essence (العين الظاهرة) in them through His Names, then those are the fields of secrets (ميادين الأسرار). If you witness His concomitance (معيته) with the cosmos through His Names, then those are the fields of lights (ميادين الأنوار). If the matter becomes confused for you, so that you see a thing and say, "It is He," then you see another thing and say, "It is not He," then you see a third thing and say, "I do not know whether it is He or not He," then those are the fields of the Presence (ميادين الحضرة). Every cosmic essence (عين كون) has a sign known by whoever traverses these fields. By that sign, he recognizes the one in whom it subsists in the world of witnessing (عالم الشهادة), within these structures (هياكل) that are dark by nature but illuminated by gnosis (المعرفة). From there, they are called by their names, like the state of this girl. We related from the narration of Mūsā ibn ‘Alī al-Akhmīmī, from Dhū al-Nūn, that he met a man in Yemen whom he had traveled to see, in a long story, in which Dhū al-Nūn said to him, "May Allah have mercy on you, what is the sign of the lover of Allah?" He replied, "My beloved, the degree of love is a lofty degree." Dhū al-Nūn said, "I would love for you to describe it to me." He said, "The lovers of Allah had their hearts split open for them, so they perceived the glory of Allah’s Majesty (عز جلال الله) with the light of their hearts. Their bodies became earthly (دنياوية), their spirits became veiled (حجبية), and their intellects became celestial (سماوية), roaming among the ranks of the angels, witnessing those matters with certainty (اليقين). So they worshipped Him to the extent of their capacity, out of love for Him, not out of desire for Paradise nor fear of the Fire." The youth gave a cry in which his soul departed.

We say that this speaker was one of the Gnostics (العارفين), for he mentioned what indicates this, namely three titles that are the only ones in the cosmos. He said: "Their bodies are earthly (دنياوية)," because [Allah] said: <<وَهُوَ الَّذِي فِي السَّمَاءِ إِلَهٌ وَفِي الْأَرْضِ إِلَهٌ>> (And He is the God in the heaven and the God in the earth). It is necessary that He leave for Him, from His realities (حقائقه), those who are with Him in the world (الدنيا), since the human being is the totality of the cosmos (مجموع العالم), and nothing is closer to him than his body, because <<وَنَحْنُ أَقْرَبُ إِلَيْهِ مِنْ حَبْلِ الْوَرِيدِ>> (And We are nearer to him than the jugular vein), which is a bodily vein. If he were to walk with his entirety, his state would be deficient. The second is: "Their intellects are celestial (سماوية)," because intellects are attributes of restriction (تقييد), for the intellect restricts, being derived from the word for tethering (*‘iqāl*). The heavens are the abode of the angels, who are restricted to their stations, for they said: <<وَمَا مِنَّا إِلَّا لَهُ مَقَامٌ مَعْلُومٌ>> (And there is none of us but has a known station). They do not transgress it; the One who brought them into existence has confined them there. This is why he explained it by saying, "roaming among the ranks of the angels." Thus, with their intellects, they are in the heavens. In the composite cosmos, there is nothing but heaven and earth. The third is: "Their spirits are veiled (حجبية)," because when the Glorified One fashioned the bodily form, He veiled Himself—rather, He veiled it—from His manifestation in its essence, and <<وَنَفَخْتُ فِيهِ مِنْ رُوحِي>> (and I breathed into him of My Spirit). Their spirits thus appeared from this veiling Spirit (الروح الحجابي). They witness their origin, knowing that it is a veil (حجاب), so that they may know Who is the Manifest One in their essences, and Who is named "so-and-so," and why he was named. Herein lie subtle secrets. The anecdotes of the Gnostic lovers are numerous. End of the 114th Section.

***

In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful.

(A Conclusion) With this, we conclude this chapter. It is called by us: The Theophanies (مجالي) of the Real to the Gnostic Lovers (العارفين المحبين) on the Platforms of Nuptials, for imparting the attributes of the lovers in love. Among these are:

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as being slain (مقتول).

This is because he is composed of Nature (طبيعة) and Spirit (روح).

> The Spirit is light, and Nature is darkness, / And both are opposites in his essence.

The two opposites are mutually repulsive, and the repulsive ones are mutually contentious. Each seeks sovereignty for itself and that the dominion should return to it. The lover is either dominated by Nature, in which case his structure (هيكل) is dark, and he loves the Real (الحق) in Creation (الخلق). He embeds the light in the darkness, relying on the principle in His saying: <<وَآيَةٌ لَهُمُ اللَّيْلُ نَسْلَخُ مِنْهُ النَّهَارَ فَإِذَا هُمْ مُظْلِمُونَ>> (And a sign for them is the night; We withdraw from it the day, and behold, they are in darkness). The day is light, so it is known that they are adjacent, even though they are opposites, and that one may be concealed within the other. So, it does not harm me to love the Real in Creation, for there is a combination of the two matters. Or, the Spirit dominates him, in which case his structure is illuminated, and he loves Creation in the Real, based on the saying: "Love Allah for the blessings with which He nourishes you." So, his love for Him is in the blessings, by His command, and his witnessed reality (مشهوده) is the Real. Whenever jealousy (الغيرة) occurs between the two opposites, and each opposite sees its desired object, it may seek to eliminate its opposite, saying, "I will kill it so that my opposite does not manifest through it instead of me." If Nature kills him, he dies while being a lover of the cosmos (الأكوان). If the Spirit kills him, he is a martyr (شهيد), alive with his Lord, receiving sustenance. Thus, every lover in the world is slain in every state, even if he is unaware of it.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as being confused/lost (تألف).

This is because Allah created him from His Name the Manifest (الظاهر) and the Hidden (الباطن), making him a world of the unseen and the witnessed. He created for him an intellect (‘aql) by which he differentiates between the ruling of the two Names, in order to establish balance between the two worlds within his essence. Then He disclosed Himself to him in His Name <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him), which confused him. This Theophany did not grant him the establishment of balance, especially since He also said to him: <<وَهُوَ السَّمِيعُ الْبَصِيرُ>> (And He is the All-Hearing, the All-Seeing). So he became lost (تلف) because he did not see a state that necessitated justice and the establishment of balance. Thus, he exited the boundary of obligation (التكليف), since only one who is intelligent, having been restricted by his intellect, is obligated. This is the attribute of the lover as being confused/lost.

### Platform and Theophany of his attribute as journeying (سائر) to Him by His Names.

This is because He disclosed Himself to him in the names of the cosmos (أسماء الكون) and disclosed Himself to him in His Most Beautiful Names (أسمائه الحسنى). He imagined, in His disclosure through the names of the cosmos, that it was a descent of the Real (الحق) concerning him, but this was not from his horizon. When he adopted the character of the Most Beautiful Names (تخلق), he was overcome by the method of the People of Allah (أهل الله) in adopting character, while imagining that the names of the cosmos were created for him, not for Allah, and that the station of the Real in them was like the station of the servant in His Most Beautiful Names. So he said, "I will not enter upon Him except with my names, and when I go out to His creation, I will go out to them with His Most Beautiful Names, adopting their character." When he entered upon Him with what he thought were his names—which were, in his view, the names of the cosmos—he saw what the Prophets saw of the signs during their night journeys (إسراء) and ascensions (معارج) in the horizons and in themselves. He saw that all of them are the Names of the Exalted One, and that the servant has no name, even the name "servant" is not his, but he adopts its character, just like the rest of the Most Beautiful Names. Thus, he knew that the journeying to Him, the entering upon Him, and the presence with Him is only by His Names, and that the names of the cosmos are His Names. He corrected the error after what had passed had passed. This witnessing (الشهود) compensated him for what he missed when he differentiated between the worshipper and the Worshipped. This is a precious Theophany (مجلى عزيز) on a great platform, which was below the ultimate goal of Abū Yazīd al-Bisṭāmī, for his ultimate goal was what he said about himself: "Draw near to me with what is not mine." This was his portion from his Lord, and he saw it as the ultimate goal. And so it is, for it is *his* ultimate goal, not *the* ultimate goal. This is another method that I have not seen tasted (ذوقا) by any of the saints (الأولياء) except the Prophets and Messengers specifically. From this Theophany, they described the Glorified One with what is called in the science of conventions the attributes of similitude (صفات التشبيه). They imagine that the Real described Himself with the attributes of creation, and they interpreted that. This witnessed reality (المشهد) grants that every name belonging to the cosmos fundamentally belongs to the Real in reality, and belongs to creation verbally but without meaning, and the creation adopts its character. Understand this.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as being a flyer (طيار).

> A sound knowledge upon which there is no dust.

This refers to what we mentioned about the names of the cosmos. He used to imagine that those names were his nest. When it became clear to him that he was not in his nest, he manifested and flew away from his being a nest, soaring in the atmosphere of his being a Name belonging to the Real (حقه). Thus, in every breath, he flies from one breath to another, because the essence of all Names belongs to the One Who <<كُلَّ يَوْمٍ هُوَ فِي شَأْنٍ>> (is, every day, in a [new] affair). There is no day in which the lover does not fly from one affair to another; this is what his witnessing grants him.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as being permanently wakeful (دائم السهر).

When he saw that the Beloved <<لَا تَأْخُذُهُ سِنَةٌ وَلَا نَوْمٌ>> (neither slumber overtakes Him nor sleep), he knew that this was due to the station of His love for preserving the world. What called him to this contemplation was the fact that the Real discloses Himself in forms (الصور), and forms have rulings. Among the rulings of some forms is sleep. Yet, he saw Him in such a form, <<لَا تَأْخُذُهُ سِنَةٌ وَلَا نَوْمٌ>> (neither slumber overtakes Him nor sleep), by virtue of that form. Thus, he knew that this was due to the station of His love for preserving the world. If the lover is the companion of his Beloved, and his Beloved possesses this attribute, then sleep is forbidden to him. The lover says, even in separation, that sleep is forbidden to him, so how much more so in witnessing (الشهود) and companionship? One of them said concerning the wakefulness of separation:

> Sleep after you is forbidden to me; / How can one who has parted from the beloveds sleep?

Therefore, sleep during witnessing is even further removed and more impossible.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as being concealed in grief (كامن الغم).

Meaning his grief is hidden and has no manifestation. The reason for this is the saying of the Exalted: <<وَمَا قَدَرُوا اللَّهَ حَقَّ قَدْرِهِ>> (And they did not estimate Allah with the estimation due to Him). Then he sees in his witnessing (شهوده) that not a single atom moves except by His permission, since He is the one who moves it with that by which it moves. And he sees in his witnessing the ill manners with which creation confronts its Creator, and what should not be attributed to Him, the implication of which is non-existence. He wishes to speak and reveal the jealousy (الغيرة) within him that love necessitates. Then he sees that this is by His permission, because he is one of those who see Allah before things—the station of Abū Bakr. So he becomes silent, and it is not possible for him to manifest his grief, because love has ruled over him that such treatment of the Beloved is inappropriate. He sees that [Allah] has given His creation authority over Him through what He made them utter, yet He excused them and sent the veil (الحجاب) before them. Thus, the grief of this lover is concealed in this world, for in the Hereafter, he will have no grief. This is why he seeks to depart from the world.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as desiring to depart from the world (الدنيا) to meet his Beloved.

This is due to what we mentioned in the preceding section, because the essence of the soul (النفس) is to seek rest, and grief is exhaustion, and its concealment is more exhausting. The world is the place of sorrows. What distinguishes this platform is his desire for a specific meeting (لقاء خاص) with his Beloved, which the Real designated, for He is the Witnessed Reality (المشهود) in every state. But when He designated certain places and made them the locus of a specific meeting, we desired it, and we cannot attain it except by departing from the abode that contradicts this meeting, which is the lower world (الدار الدنيا). The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was given the choice between remaining in the world and moving to the Hereafter, and he chose "The Highest Companion" (الرفيق الأعلى). For in the state of the world, he is in a lower companionship. It is reported in the tradition that whoever loves the meeting with Allah—meaning through death—Allah loves meeting him, and whoever dislikes the meeting with Allah, Allah dislikes meeting him. So, He meets him in death with what he dislikes, which is that He veils Himself from him and discloses Himself to those of His servants who loved meeting Him. The meeting with the Real (لقاء الحق) through death has a flavor that is not found in meeting Him during worldly life. The proportion of our meeting Him through death is like the proportion of His saying: <<سَنَفْرُغُ لَكُمْ أَيُّهَ الثَّقَلَانِ>> (We shall attend to you, O you two heavy ones [jinn and mankind]). Death, for us, is the emptying of our spirits from the management of our bodies. The love of this lover desired to attain that tasting (ذوقا), and that cannot happen except by departing from the abode of the world through death, not merely through a spiritual state (الحال). This means separating from this structure (الهيكل) with which he developed this familiarity since birth and through which he manifested—indeed, it was the cause of his manifestation. The Real separates him from this body due to the established relationship between them, which stems from the Divine jealousy (الغيرة الإلهية) over His servants due to His love for them. He does not wish there to be a relationship between them and anyone other than Him. So, He created death and tested them with it, purifying their claims of love for Him. When its ruling is concluded, John (Yaḥyā), peace be upon him, slaughters death between Paradise and the Fire, so no one in the two abodes dies. This is the reason for their desire to depart from the world to meet the Beloved, because jealousy is a trial. And He revives death by slaughtering it with a special life, just as we ruled after death:

> Indeed, people are asleep, and when they die, they awaken.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as being weary (متبرم) of the companionship that stands between him and the meeting with his Beloved.

This attribute is more general than the first concerning the lover. For the Gnostic (العارف), nothing stands between him and the meeting with his Beloved except non-existence, which is not there, and there is no Existence (الوجود) other than Him. Thus, he witnesses Him in every essence he sees. There is nothing between the lover and the Beloved except the veil of creation (حجاب الخلق). He knows that there is a Creator and a creature. He is unable to remove the companionship of this reality, for it is his very essence (عينه), and a thing cannot remove itself from itself. His soul stands between him and the meeting with his Beloved, so he is weary of his own self (نفسه) because he is a creature. His companionship with his self is essential (ذاتية) and can never be removed, so he remains perpetually weary. He is weary because he imagines that if he leaves this structure, he leaves composition, returning to a simple state with no second, becoming singular in his oneness (أحديته), which he then merges into the Oneness of the Real (أحدية الحق)—and that is the meeting. The Real would then be the resultant after the merging, not him. This makes him weary. However, the Gnostic lover is not weary of this, due to his knowledge of the matter as it truly is, as we mentioned in the *Treatise on Union* (رسالة الاتحاد).

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as being frequent in sighing (كثير التأوه).

This relates to His saying: <<إِنَّ إِبْرَاهِيمَ لَأَوَّاهٌ حَلِيمٌ>> (Indeed, Abraham was persistently sighing and forbearing). The Real described, by virtue of His Name al-Raḥmān (The Compassionate), that He has a Breath (نفسا) by which He relieves His servants, and in that Breath, the world appeared. That is why the formation of the world was made by the word *Kun* (Be!), and the letter is the cutting off of the air. The air is generated by what it is not, because the letter only appears when the air is cut off. Air is breath (نفس). Therefore, the air in the elements is the breath of Nature (نفس الطبيعة), and this is why it accepts letters, which are the sounds that appear in it when it blows. The most manifest of those sounds are the letters *Hā’* and *Hamza*, which are the furthest points of articulation for the letters, being closest to the heart, and they are the first letters of the throat, or rather, the letters of the chest. They are the first letter formed by the breather, and that is sighing (التأوه), due to its proximity to the heart, which is the locus of the breath’s exit and emission. From it, all letters appear, just as the world appears through formation from the word *Kun*. This is a wondrous secret that I shall mention in the chapter on the soul (*al-Nafs*, with a *fatḥa* on the *fā’*), if Allah wills. When the Real discloses Himself from the heart of the lover, and the eye of insight (عين البصيرة) looks upon Him—because the heart encompasses the Real—and sees the blame cast upon this natural existence (النشأة الطبيعية), even though it contains these Divine secrets, and that it appeared in the cosmos from the Breath of the Compassionate (نفس الرحمن), yet it is blamed and its worth is unknown, the lover sighs frequently due to this affliction. He sees the clarity and manifestation [of the Real], while people are in blindness concerning it and do not perceive. So he sighs out of jealousy for Allah (غيرة على الله) and compassion for the veiled ones (المحجوبين), because the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, made the perfection of faith in the believer that he should love for his brother what he loves for himself. Therefore, he grieves for those whom Allah has deprived of this witnessing, and he sighs out of his love for his Beloved, because of the blindness of creation toward Him that he observes. It is characteristic of the lover to have compassion for the Beloved, for love grants that.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as finding rest in the speech of his Beloved and His remembrance (ذكره) through the recitation of His remembrance.

The Exalted said: <<إِنَّا نَحْنُ نَزَّلْنَا الذِّكْرَ>> (Indeed, We have sent down the Remembrance [al-Dhikr]), thus calling His speech Remembrance. Know that the origin of the cosmos’s existence was not from any Divine Attribute except specifically the Attribute of Speech (صفة الكلام). The cosmos knew nothing of Him except His speech, and it was that which was heard, and it found delight in hearing it, so it could not but come into being. For this reason, hearing is naturally disposed to movement, agitation, and transition in the hearers, because when the hearer heard the word *Kun* (Be!), he transitioned and moved from the state of non-existence to the state of Existence (الوجود), and thus was formed. From this comes the origin of the movement of the People of Audition (أهل السماع), who are the people of ecstasy (وجد). It is not necessary for one who [is in this state]—for ecstasy inherently necessitates what it necessitates—but the Beloved differs. Love, ecstasy, yearning (الشوق), and all the attributes of love are descriptions of love, regardless of who the Beloved is. However, in this book, I have specialized in the love related to Allah, Who is the Beloved in reality, even if He is not consciously perceived in certain places by some people, but is consciously perceived by others, who are the Gnostics (العارفون). They love none but Allah, even while they love their spirits, their families, and their companions. Know this. Even some righteous people related to us that Qays the Mad (al-Majnūn) was one of the lovers of Allah, and Laylā was made his veil (حجابه). He was one of the passionately devoted. I derived the truth of this saying from his anecdote in which he said to Laylā, "Away from me, for your love has distracted me from you." He neither brought her near nor drew her close. It is characteristic of love that the lover seeks connection with the Beloved, and this action contradicts love. It is also characteristic of the lover to swoon upon the sudden arrival of the Beloved and to be stunned. Yet, this one says to her, "Away from me," and was neither stunned nor annihilated (فنى). Thus, the truth of what this Gnostic said concerning Qays the Mad was confirmed for me by this action. It is not far-fetched, for Allah has treasures among His servants. From this perspective, the lovers find rest in the speech of the Beloved and His remembrance. The Qur’an is His speech and it is Remembrance, so they prefer nothing over its recitation, because they act as His deputies in it, as if He were the Speaker, as He said: <<فَأَجِرْهُ حَتَّى يَسْمَعَ كَلَامَ اللَّهِ>> (Then grant him protection until he hears the Word of Allah). The reciter is none other than Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him. Thus, the People of the Qur’an are the People of Allah and His chosen ones; they are the beloved lovers.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as conforming to the desires (محاب) of his Beloved.

This is an attribute specific only to the lovers of Allah, due to the fact that the Exalted is neither limited nor restricted. He is the One Who discloses Himself in the Name the Near (القريب) just as He discloses Himself in the Name the Distant (البعيد); thus, He is the Distant, the Near. The lover said: "Everything the Beloved does is beloved." So, if He enacts distance, then distance from the Beloved is his beloved, because it is the Beloved’s beloved. He loves it for the sake of the Beloved’s love, not for his own self. He does not love it for the sake of the Beloved’s love, not for his own self, until the Beloved becomes an attribute of his. When the Beloved is among the attributes of the lover, He subsists in him. When He subsists in him, the lover is at the ultimate degree of union (الوصلة) in the very essence of distance—a more complete union than he has in proximity, because in proximity, he is by the attribute of his own self, not by the attribute of his Beloved. It is not sound for two causes to subsist in one locus for a single effect. Thus, he only loves proximity for his own self, just as he only loves distance by means of his Beloved. Therefore, his love in distance is more perfect than his love in proximity. We have the following verses concerning this meaning:

> A passion between grace and beauty, / Which the strong among men endure.
> And every weak heart is too feeble for it, / One who turns over in bliss and indulgence.
> And my turning over in abandonment (الهجران) is, for me, / Sweeter than embracing in union (الوصال).
> For in union, I am the slave of my own self, / But in abandonment, I am the slave of the Masters.
> And my occupation with the Beloved in every aspect / Is dearer to me than my occupation with my own state.

In this poetry is the preference for the Beloved’s desired effects, and it contains what we alluded to in our preceding discussion. As for our saying that the Beloved is an attribute of the lover, this is confirmed by His saying: "When I love him, I am his hearing and his sight." He made the essence of the servant’s hearing and sight His own, thus establishing that He is his attribute. Therefore, the lover only loves distance by means of his Beloved, and this is the ultimate union in the very essence of distance.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as fearing the abandonment of reverence (الحرمة) in the performance of service (الخدمة).

Only an intermediate Gnostic (عارف متوسط) who has not reached the verification (التحقيق) of gnosis fears this, although he perceives it without tasting (ذوق) other than the tasting of perception. He is a lover, and the lover is obedient to his Beloved in all His commands. The verification of the matter grants that the Commander is the very essence of the commanded, and the lover is the very essence of the Beloved. However, the manifest appears according to what the reality of the manifestation grants. Through the manifestations, variations appear outwardly, and rulings and names differ. Through them, the obedient and the disobedient appear. The one who is in the station of perception (مقام الشعور) and has not reached the limit of assigning things their proper stations outwardly fears that something contradicting reverence might issue from him in his service, since he says, "There is none but He," as is the view of those who see the entities (الأعيان) as a single essence but do not know how. Thus, he continually behaves improperly because he took this idea without tasting. This is the doctrine of those who believe that the spirit governing human bodies is one spirit, and that the essence of Zayd’s spirit is the essence of ‘Amr’s spirit. This contains an error that we have mentioned elsewhere: it necessitates that what Zayd knows, ‘Amr does not ignore, because the knowing part of each person is the essence of his spirit, and it is one, and a single thing cannot be both knowing and ignorant of the same thing. So, the lover fears that if a lack of reverence issues from him through a slip or error, he might rely upon what we mentioned after its occurrence, leading to a lack of concern for what appears from him. But love refuses anything but reverence for the Beloved, even if the lover is proud of his love due to the dominance of love over him, and even if he sees himself as the very essence of his Beloved, saying:

> I am the one I love, and the one I love is I.

This, and nothing else, is the cause of his fear.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as deeming the much from himself little in relation to his Lord, and deeming the little from his Beloved much.

This is because he differentiates between his being a lover, due to the brokenness, humility, astonishment, and confusion he sees in himself, which are the effects of love in the lovers, and he sees the pride, haughtiness, sovereignty, and self-admiration of the Beloved over him. Thus, he sees that if he gives Him everything he owns, it is little compared to what He gave him of Himself, and that the right of his Beloved is greater to him than his own right; indeed, he sees no right for himself, even though, in reality, he strives only for his own right—this is what love grants him. There was a slave named Iyās whom one of the kings loved. One of the king’s companions entered and saw the slave’s feet in the king’s lap, and the king was massaging them. He was astonished. Iyās said, "O man, these are not the feet of Iyās; this is the heart of the King in His lap, which He is massaging." This is the meaning of our saying that the lover strives for his own right, for he finds immense pleasure in that action, which he cannot attain except through that action. The Beloved is gracious to him by enabling him to experience the pleasure that the lover derives from the Beloved. Thus, the lover sees that anything that comes from the Beloved is much; it is the favor of a Master upon a slave. And anything that comes from the lover in relation to the Beloved, even the destruction of the soul and the vital spirit (المهجة) for His pleasure, is little, because it is the obedience of a slave to a benevolent Master. <<وَمَا قَدَرُوا اللَّهَ حَقَّ قَدْرِهِ>> (And they did not estimate Allah with the estimation due to Him). The Beloved is rich, so His little is much. The lover is poor, so his much is little. However, even though this is the attribute of the lover according to them, it is the attribute of a lover deficient in gnosis (ناقص المعرفة), whose abundant love is based on blindness. For if the lover were the creature, he would have nothing to deem little or much. But if the Beloved is Allah, He deems the little from His servant much, which is His saying: <<فَاتَّقُوا اللَّهَ مَا اسْتَطَعْتُمْ>> (So fear Allah as much as you are able) and <<لَا يُكَلِّفُ اللَّهُ نَفْسًا إِلَّا وُسْعَهَا>> (Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity). As for his deeming the much little in relation to his beloved servants, what is with Allah has no end, and the entry of the infinite into existence is impossible. Everything that enters existence is finite. When the finite is added to the infinite, it appears as if it were little or as if it were nothing, even if it is much. This is a contemplation that would take long, so we have abbreviated it.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as embracing the obedience (طاعة) of his Beloved and shunning opposition (مخالفته).

Their poet said:

> You disobey the God while manifesting love for Him? / This is an impossible and wondrous analogy.
> If your love were sincere, you would obey Him; / Indeed, the lover is obedient to the one he loves.

The lover is a servant, and the servant is one who adheres to the commands of his Master and avoids opposing His commands and prohibitions. He does not see Him where He forbade, nor does he miss Him where He commanded. He remains standing before Him. When He commands him, this lover sees that He has favored him by employing him and commanding him, and that this is due to His care for him. Even if he loses sight and witnessing (مشاهدته) in what occupies him, he is in bliss and pleasure by acting according to the decrees of his Master and by His permission. If the Beloved is Allah, then the Beloved’s command to him is his supplication (دعاؤه) and his desire for what occurs to him and what he loves. Then, he dislikes things, so he supplicates to Him in the form of a prohibition, such as His saying: <<رَبَّنَا لَا تُزِغْ قُلُوبَنَا>> (Our Lord, do not let our hearts deviate), and <<وَلَا تَحْمِلْ عَلَيْنَا إِصْرًا>> (and do not lay upon us a burden), and <<وَلَا تُحَمِّلْنَا مَا لَا طَاقَةَ لَنَا بِهِ>> (and do not burden us with that which we have no capacity for). This is a request in the form of a prohibition. Thus, the command and prohibition have issued from the servant to his Master. The Real’s response to this servant, by virtue of His being the Beloved of this servant, is like the servant’s obedience to the commands of his Master and his shunning of opposition to Him.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as being completely outside of himself (خارج عن نفسه بالكلية).

Know that the self (نفس) of a person, by which he is distinguished from many creatures, is only his will (إرادته). If he abandons his will for what his Beloved wills for him, he has completely exited his self, and he has no independent action. If his Beloved wills a certain matter for him or through him, and this lover knows what his Beloved wills from him or by him, he hastens or prepares himself to accept that. He sees that this preparation and hastening stem from the sovereignty of love that rules over him. The Beloved does not see in His lover anyone who contends with Him regarding what He wills for him or from him, because the lover has completely exited his self for Him, having no will alongside Him. However, this is with the existence of his self and his seeking connection with Him. If it were not so, he would be at the level of inanimate matter, which has no will, and he would have no pleasure except the pleasure related to the Beloved’s delight in what He sees of his acceptance. For the lover of Allah, Allah revealed to Moses (Mūsā), "O son of Adam, I created things for your sake"—meaning the world and the Hereafter—because he is the intended Essence (العين المقصودة), and he is the chief of the beloveds, Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him. Thus, everything is subservient to this human existence (النشأة الإنسانية): the celestial spheres and what they contain, and the stars and their courses—this is in the world. As for the Hereafter, it contains what no eye has seen, no ear has heard, and has not occurred to the heart of man, up to the end of the matter, which is the Divine Theophany (التجلي الإلهي) on the Day of the Greatest Gathering (يوم الزور الأعظم). This is the meaning of the lover being completely outside of himself in everything that the Beloved might need, but what the Beloved has no need for, and from which no pleasure or joy returns to Him, does not fall under this chapter.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as not seeking blood-money (الدية) for his slaying.

We described him earlier as being slain. The slaying of the lover is martyrdom (شهادة), so his slaying is his life, and there is no blood-money for the living. Blood-money is only paid for the slain who dies, for whom it was legislated. For the lover of Allah, since the servant is beloved, his will is effective, and the lover has no will that contends with His will. The slain has no will. Whoever is by the will of his Beloved has no will, even if he is a willing agent, and he has no blood-money because the living have no blood-money. The essential life (الحياة الذاتية) belongs to him, which is the love of the obligatory duties (الفرائض). If he performs them, Allah loves him. In the supererogatory acts (النوافل), He is the servant’s hearing and sight. In the obligatory duties, the servant is the hearing and sight of the Real. For this reason, the world subsists, for Allah does not look upon the world except with the sight of this servant, so the world does not perish due to the correspondence. If He were to look upon the world with His own sight, the world would be consumed by the splendors of His Face (سبحات وجهه). Thus, the Real looks upon the world with the sight of the Perfect Human (الكامل) created upon His Form, who is the very essence of the veil (الحجاب) between the world and the consuming splendors.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as enduring adversity (الضراء) from which Nature (الطبع) recoils, due to the management of his existence with which his Beloved charged him.

The human being is a composite of Nature and Light (النور). Nature seeks him, and Light seeks him. The Light is charged to be patient and to abandon much of what is proper for it and what its reality seeks, due to the interests sought by Nature. The Light, which is the Spirit (الروح), is commanded to give Nature its due right. This is His saying, peace and blessings be upon him, to the one who asked him, "Whom should I honor most?" He said, "Your mother," three times, and then on the fourth, "Then your father." Thus, he prioritized honoring the mother over the father, and Nature is the mother. This is also His saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Indeed, your self (نفسك) has a right over you"—which is the animal soul—"and your eye has a right over you." All of this is from the rights of the mother, which is the nature of the human being. His father is the Divine Spirit (الروح الإلهي), which is the Light. If he abandons many things he loves, by virtue of his luminosity, he is described as being afflicted (مضرور), and he is commanded to be patient. This is the meaning of enduring adversity, even though his reality recoils from it, but the command of Allah is obligatory. Then He said to him concerning his patience: <<وَاصْبِرْ وَمَا صَبْرُكَ إِلَّا بِاللَّهِ>> (And be patient, and your patience is not but through Allah). Allah named Himself with the Name al-Ṣabūr (The Patient). It is as if He said to him: "I, in the glory of My Majesty, have described Myself as being harmed, yet I am forbearing and patient, and I named Myself al-Ṣabūr. I am neither commanded nor restricted, yet I placed Myself under the desires of My creation and abandoned what is proper for Me for what is proper for My creation, preferring their concern and out of mercy for them. You are more deserving of enduring adversity through Me"—meaning, because of My command and because of My being Patient with the harm of My creation when they describe Me with what My Majesty does not necessitate. This is from Allah’s being the Beloved in this Theophany. As for his being so because his Beloved charged him with the management of his natural existence: if the Beloved is Creation and the Lover is the Real, then the form of the obligation is what the servant requests from his Master—if he knows he is beloved to his Master—concerning the management of his interests, provided it conforms to His purposes and desires. The Real then does that with him. This is the meaning by which the lover is attributed.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as being heart-wandering (هائم القلب).

Since the heart (القلب) was named thus due to the frequency of its transformations (*taṣarrufāt*) and turning over (*taqlīb*), its aspects and orientations multiplied. This is the characteristic of the wanderer (الهائم), especially if the Real (الحق) appears to him in every aspect he turns toward and in every course he takes. He is looking at the very essence of his Beloved in every aspect. For the lover of Allah, <<كُلَّ يَوْمٍ هُوَ فِي شَأْنٍ>> (Every day He is in a [new] affair). "I have not hesitated concerning anything I am going to do." The multiplicity of aspects in a single matter leads to hesitation as to which one to perform, even though all of them are pleasing to the Beloved. We do not know the most pleasing, though He knows the most pleasing concerning us. However, we know the most pleasing between the supererogatory acts (النوافل) and the obligatory duties (الفرائض), so we say the obligatory duties are more pleasing. But when they gather by the ruling of choice, such as an expiation (كفارة) that involves choice, the most pleasing is not known except by a renewed definition. Similarly, the most pleasing among the supererogatory acts is not known except by Divine instruction. The supererogatory acts are numerous, and none of them is without being pleasing from one aspect and more pleasing from another. Thus, a new definition is necessary. In such a case, the lover is heart-wandering, meaning perplexed regarding the aspects in which he wishes to turn.

### Platform and Theophany of the attribute of the lover as preferring his Beloved over every companion (مصحوب).

Since the entire cosmos, every part of it, holds a trust (أمانة) for the human being, and the human being is charged with fulfilling this trust—and these trusts are numerous, with specific times for their performance, having a trust in every moment—among these is what Abu Talib drew attention to: that the celestial sphere moves by the breaths of the human being, or rather, by the breath of every breather. The human being is specifically intended in this mention because the celestial realm moves with his movement and follows him wherever he is. Thus, the cosmos continually accompanies the human being for this reason. Furthermore, the human being is dependent upon these trusts held by the cosmos. Yet, despite their dependence upon them, the lovers (المحبين) among the men of God, the Gnostics (العارفين), occupy themselves with what their Beloved (محبوبهم) has commanded them. They look upon Him with love and passionate devotion, for His love has enslaved them and made them wander between His distance and His nearness. From this perspective, they are described as preferring Him over every companion, because He is their Companion, according to His saying: <<وَهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ مَا كُنْتُمْ>> (And He is with you wherever you are). Everyone in the cosmos also accompanies the human being because of the trust (أمانة) that is in his hand. Therefore, due to his love for God, the human being prefers the Divine Presence (جناب الله) over every companion.

Sahl was asked, "What is sustenance (القوت)?" He replied, "Allah." He was told, "We only desire that by which life is maintained." He replied, "Allah." For he saw nothing but Allah. When they pressed him, saying, "We only desire that by which this physical body is sustained," and he saw that they did not understand him, he shifted to another answer and said, "Leave the dwellings to their Builder; if He wills, He will build them up, and if He wills, He will destroy them." He means that it is not the concern of the subtle human essence (اللطيفة الإنسانية) to accompany this specific physical structure. Rather, it must occupy itself with what the Beloved (المحبوب)—Who is the very essence of its life and existence (وجودها)—has charged it with. Whatever house He places it in, it will inhabit. This is if he speaks of the non-detachment from the natural constitution (النشأة الطبيعية), as we say and as the Unveiling (الكشف) granted him. But if he speaks of detachment from nature and the cessation of connection, he is in any case among those who prefer God over every companion.

The Lover, God (المحب الله), preferred the human being, as His beloved, over the entire cosmos. He granted him the Perfect Form (الصورة الكاملة), which He did not grant to any other category of the cosmos. Even though the cosmos is described as obedient and glorifying God (التسبيح), He preferred the human being over every companion. The Exalted said: <<وَإِذْ قَالَ رَبُّكَ لِلْمَلَائِكَةِ إِنِّي جَاعِلٌ فِي الْأَرْضِ خَلِيفَةً>> (And when your Lord said to the angels, 'Indeed, I am going to place upon the earth a vicegerent'). He gave him all the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية). Thus, the human being glorifies Him with every Divine Name that has a connection to the cosmos, magnifying and exalting Him—not merely the name of the small bowl (القصعة) and the tiny bowl (القصيعة), which is the interpretation adopted by those who lack knowledge of the nobility of matters. For this reason, the angels said: <<نُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِكَ وَنُقَدِّسُ لَكَ>> (We exalt [You] with Your praise and sanctify You). And nothing is sanctified or glorified except by His Names. So, He informed them that God has Names in the cosmos by which the angels have neither glorified nor sanctified Him, and Adam knew them. When He presented what He had created, of which the angels had no knowledge, He said: <<أَنْبِئُونِي بِأَسْمَاءِ هَؤُلَاءِ>> (Inform Me of the names of these) by which you glorify and sanctify Me. They said: <<قَالُوا لَا عِلْمَ لَنَا>> (They said, 'We have no knowledge'). Then He said to Adam: <<أَنْبِئْهُمْ بِأَسْمَائِهِمْ>> (Inform them of their names). When Adam informed them of their names, they knew that God had Names of which they had no knowledge, and that these created beings glorified Him by them, and Adam knew them. Thus, Adam glorified God by them. Just as he said to the angels when they circumambulated the House (the Kaaba), "What were you saying?" The angels replied, "In our circumambulation before you, we were saying: *Subhan Allah, wal-hamdulillah, wa la ilaha illa Allah, wa Allahu Akbar* (Glory be to God, and praise be to God, and there is no god but God, and God is Greatest)." Adam said to them, "And I will add for you: *La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah* (There is no power nor strength except with God)." God granted this to him from a treasure beneath the Throne that the angels did not know. If the commentator, by his saying "even the small bowl and the tiny bowl," had intended the Divine Name directed toward the small and the great, so that the small glorifies Him in its smallness in a way that the great does not glorify Him in its greatness, he would have been correct. But he merely intended the literal words *al-qaṣʿa* and *al-quṣayʿa*, and there is no nobility in such a thing, for it refers to conventional usage, as it has a name composed of letters in every language that does not resemble the name in another language. The only thing intended is the benefit that parallels the angels' boast over the human being that they are glorifying and sanctifying, so God showed them the nobility of Adam in response to their claim, which is what we have mentioned and nothing else. There is nothing nobler among created beings than the angel, yet the Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل) was favored over him by the knowledge of the Names. Thus, in this Divine Presence (الحضرة) and this station (المقام), the human being is superior. This is the extent of the preference of the Real (الحق) for him.

(Platform and Manifestation) The description of the Lover as Annihilation in Affirmation (محو في إثبات).

As for his affirmation (إثباته), it appears in his being charged with duties (تكليفه) and in the physical acts of worship, specifically his prayer, which God divided between Himself and His servant, thereby affirming him. As for his annihilation (محوه) within this affirmation, it is His saying: <<وَاللَّهُ خَلَقَكُمْ وَمَا تَعْمَلُونَ>> (And Allah created you and what you do), and His saying: <<لَيْسَ لَكَ مِنَ الْأَمْرِ شَيْءٌ>> (You have no say in the matter whatsoever), and His saying: <<إِنَّ الْأَمْرَ كُلَّهُ لِلَّهِ>> (Indeed, the command belongs entirely to Allah), and His saying: <<وَمَا رَمَيْتَ إِذْ رَمَيْتَ وَلَكِنَّ اللَّهَ رَمَى>> (And you did not throw when you threw, but Allah threw), and His saying: <<مِمَّا جَعَلَكُمْ مُسْتَخْلَفِينَ فِيهِ>> (In that which He has made you successors). This is the utmost clarity from the Book of God: annihilation within affirmation. The lover has no disposal except in that into which he is disposed. His love has now constrained him, desiring something other than what the Beloved desires for him. The Reality (الحقيقة) in the matter itself refuses anything else. Everything that proceeds from him is God's creation; he is the acted upon, not the actor. He is the locus where matters flow upon him. Thus, he is annihilation in affirmation. The Lover, God (المحب الله), is annihilation in affirmation. The eye only falls upon the act of the servant—this is the annihilation (محو) of the Real (الحق). Yet, rational proof and Unveiling (الكشف) only yield the existence (وجود) of the Real, not the existence of the servant or the cosmos. This is the affirmation (إثبات) of the Real. Thus, it is annihilation in the world of witnessing (عالم الشهادة) and affirmation in the Presence of Contemplation (حضرة الشهود).

(Platform and Manifestation) The description of the Lover as having submitted himself to what his Beloved desires of him.

This is because when love intervened between him and the sight of causes, and he had no gaze left except toward the Presence of his Beloved (محبوبه), the Exalted, he became ignorant of what the cosmos needs from him. Yet, in the matter itself, he must render to the cosmos the rights it demands of him, as the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "And your visitor has a right over you." Thus, he brought forth that which includes the entire cosmos, which is the visit (الزيارة). This is from the comprehensive words (جوامع كلمه) of the Prophet. This lover submits himself to what his Beloved desires of him. He knows the rights the cosmos has over him, based on what his Beloved willed for him regarding his disposal in that into which He disposed him. The Real (الحق) is Wise, so He only moves him in a specific action and the performance of a specific right demanded by whoever is in the cosmos at that time. Thus, he knows the cosmos through God, and he gains the witnessing (شهود) of the Real. This is the saying of the Veracious One (al-Ṣiddīq): "I have not seen a thing except that I saw God before it." He witnessed the essence of the cosmos within the witnessing of God. The Lover, God (المحب الله), since in the matter itself the Essence (ذات) of the Exalted Real does not accept disposal within Itself, and He placed in the souls of the cosmos the need for Him regarding their subsistence (بقاؤهم), their interests, and the fulfillment of their purposes, it is as if He has submitted Himself to everything they desire from Him and desire by Him. For this reason, if they ask Him for something whose time has not yet come, He says to them: <<سَنَفْرُغُ لَكُمْ>> (We will attend to you). He is the Actor in every state, yet His Essence is not the locus for the manifestation of effects. Thus, the submission (التوطئة) has occurred: He is prepared for what the cosmos needs, not for Himself. And in everything He brings into existence, there is a glorification (تسبيح) that is the sustenance (غذاء) of that existent thing. For this reason, the Exalted informed us that there is nothing <<إِلَّا يُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِهِ>> (except that it glorifies Him with His praise). We have mentioned this in the station of Spiritual Chivalry (مقام الفتوة).

(Platform and Manifestation) The description of the Lover as intermingled in attributes (متداخل الصفات).

This is because the lover seeks connection (الاتصال) with the Beloved and seeks to follow the Beloved's will. Yet, the Beloved may will something that contradicts connection. Thus, the attributes of the lover are intermingled in such a case. The Lover, God (المحب الله), is the First (الأول) from the very essence of what He is the Last (الآخر). So, His Lastness enters into His Firstness, and His Firstness enters into His Lastness, and there is nothing there but His Essence. His Firstness is His Essence, and His Lastness is His servant, who is His beloved. Thus, His attributes are intermingled with the attributes of His beloved. If you say "servant," you have not been exclusive; and if you say "Lord," you have not been exclusive; yet you are truthful in both matters. This is the ruling of intermingling (التداخل).

(Platform and Manifestation) The description of the Lover as having no rest (نفس) with his Beloved.

He means that he is not at ease with his Beloved because he is observing his Beloved in every breath, seeing where His desires lie, and acting upon them. Thus, he never ceases to be in distress (عناء) due to the exertion of effort (بذل المجهود) to attain the Beloved's satisfaction, and that satisfaction is unknown. Therefore, there is no rest for the lover. This is the meaning of their saying, "He has no rest (نفس)," meaning he does not rest from the relief (التنفيس), which is the removal of distress and hardship. This is the description of the lover who is truthful in his love. The Lover, God (المحب الله), His saying: <<كُلَّ يَوْمٍ هُوَ فِي شَأْنٍ>> (Every day He is in [some] affair). He only acts concerning the rights of His servants, and He only intends His beloved ones among His servants. The rest benefit by way of dependence, eating the remnants of their tables. Thus, His occupation is with their interests, both in this world and the Hereafter. However, He is described as not being touched by weariness (لغوب). The Exalted says: <<وَلَقَدْ خَلَقْنَا السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضَ وَمَا بَيْنَهُمَا فِي سِتَّةِ أَيَّامٍ وَمَا مَسَّنَا مِنْ لُغُوبٍ>> (And We did certainly create the heavens and the earth and what is between them in six days, and no weariness touched Us). And His saying: <<أَفَعَيِينَا بِالْخَلْقِ الْأَوَّلِ بَلْ هُمْ فِي لَبْسٍ مِنْ خَلْقٍ جَدِيدٍ>> (Were We fatigued by the first creation? But they are in confusion over a new creation)—meaning that in every breath, He, the Exalted, is in a new creation concerning His servants, which is His saying: <<كُلَّ يَوْمٍ هُوَ فِي شَأْنٍ>>. And He said concerning the people of bliss: <<لَا يَمَسُّهُمْ فِيهَا نَصَبٌ>> (No fatigue will touch them therein), despite the fact that they are constantly acting concerning the right of God, not the right of their own souls. Then, that returns to them, though they do not intend it for the sake of its return. Rather, the realities necessitate this. For this reason, the lover is described as having no rest with his Beloved.

(Platform and Manifestation) The description of the Lover as being wholly for his Beloved.

This is because he is a totality (مجموع), and by virtue of his totality, his essence appeared. His units (آحاده) belong to God, since Oneness (الأحدية) belongs to God, and the totality is nothing but these units. Thus, he is wholly for God. For when any unit of the totality is multiplied by the One Real (الواحد الحق), the result is the One Real. This is the meaning of "wholly for his Beloved." He is the unit of the totality. Based on this, if the Lover is God (المحب الله), then the totality, in relation to God and His Oneness, is merely the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية), which are the ninety-nine. Multiplicity (الكثرة) appeared in the Names, so the name "totality" is valid. The units of this totality are the essence of each Name individually, which demands from the servant a single reality wherein its sovereignty appears, and it must be only one. Thus, you multiply the One by the One, and the witnessed result is the one servant, who is the beloved. So, he is wholly for God because all the Names manifest their rulings in the servant, and the Names belong to God. Therefore, the totality belongs to the servant who is beloved by God. There is nothing in the Divine Presence (الحضرة الإلهية) except for the beloved servant, for <<إِنَّ اللَّهَ بِذَاتِهِ غَنِيٌّ عَنِ الْعَالَمِينَ>> (Indeed, Allah, by His Essence, is independent of the worlds). He is independent of multiplicity and of the indication toward Him.

(Platform and Manifestation) The description of the Lover as reproaching himself concerning the right of his Beloved.
